content:
Posted: December 17, 2014
Early Access Review
								First off, I'm a backer of the game's Kickstarter, though I honestly haven't been paying attention to the game's development until I was reminded that it existed. I don't even remember what level I backed at (probably $50?). So a little disclosure that this review is biased.Anyway, the tl;dr is that the game has potential, but it's not especially fun in its current stage.The longer review is that, in the state it is right now, the game isn't very fun. It's not especially buggy - I had a few collision problems and got stuck once, but that's also called "any given session of Skyrim" so it's not something to go crazy about on a pre-Alpha.The big issue is that so many systems are not yet implemented that it's hard to get a real feel for how the game really will be. Plus, since the agents all start out effectively at level 1, with no points in any but their core abilities, I can't really play with any special abilities or get a feel for what makes the classes different outside of appearance and a little gimmick. Combat is just pointless at this stage - my guys get torn apart, even in cover, which might suggest a balance issue as well. The interface is messy and the fonts are too small, making it hard to read, and, though I have lots of missions available I wind up very confused as to where to go and what do.But, again, it's a pre-Alpha. This is effectively working code, and nothing more. It's not until Beta that you have everything implemented, so it'll be a while until I get to play "Satellite Reign." What I have right now is just the barebones of what will one be that game.The potential is there, though.Firstly, the graphics look great, though the game isn't optimized at the least and runs like crap, though my computer is fairly decent (I run most modern games on max settings). The city map oozes detail and is both reminiscent of Syndicate AND very, very Cyberpunk. Just wandering around looking at things is nice.Next, the missions are varied and usually have multiple ways to complete them, including mulitple site entrances, hackable terminals, and even side missions that make completing the main missions easier; for instance, one side mission has me suborning a cyber-clinic to hack enemy agent implants, thus making combat easier across the board. Another has me contacting an info dealer which leads to better intel on other missions. This means you've got a lot of flexibility in how to do things. Or you can just run and gun.The Combat, at this stage, feels unbalanced and my agents are very weak. However, it's got potential. The cover system is very organic, resembling a real-time X-Com: Enemy Unknown, and watching firefights unfold is impressive. The enemies seems dumb as dirt right now, but hopefully that will be improved. In any case, they are smart enough to take cover and call for reinforcements, and the game incorporates using hacking to shut that nonsense down, so, as with eveything else, the potential is there.I can't tell much about the rest of the game, but what I played feels like a decent taste of things to come.So, would I recommend you BUY it? No, not at this stage.However, I DO recommend that, if you love Syndicate, Cyberpunk, or, heck, X-Com and other top-down tactical games, following Satellite Reign and picking it up when it hits Beta or goes Gold.

content:
Posted: July 26, 2015
Early Access Review
								Let's just get this out of the way: this game has semi-recently come out of alpha and it shows--it's a bit rough around the edges.  That needed to be said so you can understand the full context of the following: it is totally worth it.  This is a great game that I just sit down and sink hours into.  The open world is there for you to explore and has enough to keep you busy and engaged without eventually feeling mundane.  The skills and tools your agents have offer a variety of possible solutions to your various challenges (although some are easier than others).  Additionally, using informants doesn't feel like a cheat so much as proper heist planning: casing the joint, greasing a few palms, and getting insight into who has the actually run on the vault.Also, wIth the open world with open ended solutions the developers made a great choice: death of your agents is not the end nor an unbearable setback.  It's problematic and costs you time, XP, and/or money but it's not crippeling.  Agent resurrection is always available, new clones can be acquired, and passive syphoning of ATMs for cash allows you to make up for mistakes or ops that did not go as planned. This encourages the experimentation a game like this needs to enable while still keeping a steady difficulty curve.All I can say is this game is very fun and doesn't straight jacket you while still feeling all proper and cyberpunk.  The gameplay experience is worth the rough edges and I eagerly look forward to every update.  Keep on keep'en on 5 Lives.

content:
Posted: July 27, 2016
												(Story Complete) Satellite Reign is a squad based RTS where you take 4 opratives into enemy headquarters to steal sensitive intel, weapon prototypes, kill targets, or help informants escape. I went into this game thinking I would like it and came away loving it. The highlights to Satellite Reign- Atmosphere : The story takes a backseat but neo-future artstyle and sound design are great.- Infiltrator & Sniper : The best two classes of your squad by far. Stealth ops is generally the course of action. These two classes are much more useful than Soldier or Support.- Infiltrator Hacking : Making enemies kill enemies.- Enemy Patrol AI : Satellite Reign does a great job of balancing the predictability of enemy patrol routes & reinforcements.The low points of Satellite Reign- Cover system : the cover points on the map are great in the beginning of the game and sketchy/missing in the reamining areas. You can find yourself stuck in walls at times.- Soldier & Support : The game will keep reinforments coming if you are alerted so a full on attack never feels like a viable option. Support has some great abilities but nothing the feels like you care if he is on the mission or not.- Headquarter resource respawn : clearing an area just is see the cameras and turrets respawn is not fun.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 11, 2015
												My first experience of the Syndicate Universe was playing the "Bullfrog" Syndicate Wars port on the Playstation when it first came out. Never played anything like it at the time. It was completely alien, cold and heartless in a way my younger gaming self hadn't experienced since Doom, or possibly Mechwarrior. I sunk countless hours into that game and have yearned for something similar since. So when this game was announced, I crowdfunded it and followed it from inception.I have to say, this isn't Syndicate or even Syndicate Wars. It's something of a blend of the two, with a nod towards modern sensibilities. I like it. I like this alot. For a start, it's beautiful looking - everything is slicked with rain and dingy. The soundtrack is spot on. It's the cold synth hell of a totalitarian neon-nightmare in audible form - very Vangelis. I'd liked to have seen some of the augs visibly change the clone models though, or maybe the various attachments on the weapons visibly change the look of the weapon. That's me being picky and probably spoiled via "AAA" titles. The visuals are lovely in any event, but could have done with being a bit more "grim." Sometimes it reminds me of the World of Warcraft graphical style, which I don't think suits the source material or the feel of the title.The open world maps are large and simply gorgeous. The various districts seem alive and populated, there's traffic etc. The only problem I have is that it doesn't seem "alive." Again, this is probably an issue with me: the many years since the original Syndicate have given us GTA and FarCry - large, populated worlds that respond to player choices etc. I just wish the cities in this game responded to the gun-fights and hacking activities of the agents. It does seem somewhat lifeless, but in retrospect this is probably more a nod to the "feel" of the original games. It doesn't detract from the fun though.There's a multitude of choice in terms of how you can approach the various missions and a myriad of ways to actually infiltrate a base or assasinate a target etc. It really does offer that wide ranging choice to individual playstyles.Give this a go. Support the developers on this one.

content:
Posted: March 19, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is going to be a modern classic for the more hardcore-minded PC gamer crowd.  I can tell just by the design so far. Right now, the game is not near anywhere done. But you can already tell its going to be a winner. I'm probably not going to put more than 5 hours in until beta, because there is a long road ahead. But just with this design (total throwback to days before the conventions of genre were not universal like they are now) and the cyberpunk esthetic (looks great) and off-the-rails freedom this game allows, and ... well let's just say its going to be a lot of fun. For those who aren't super-old and familiar with the originals:   top down view. Real time tactical gameplay. Four [set] character types on your team you control.  Non-linear gameplay (you have your choice of missions in large city map). Guns. Research. Murder, hacking & corporations. What could go wrong? Put this on your wishlist and buy it next sale, you won't be disappointed if you like the look of the screenshots or videos, you'll like this game.

content:
Posted: August 28, 2015
												Satellite reign puts you on charge of 4 agents that have to fulfill missions in order to gain authority and climb the enterprise ladder. You can either choose to shoot your way through or hack and sneak your way to the objective.This game could have been a really good one, but it only will get a 7/10 from me for some things it just does horrible and that could have been done way better easily.Pros:- More or less open world to explore and seek missions- Different classes that can be tailored toward your needs- Good looking world design and graphics- actually challenging- you always have the choice of playstyleCons:- Repetitive after a while. The missions are always the same: get into base X, sometimes get NPC X and escort him, but nothing really interesting.- Horrible menus and map design, all characters, map and loadout are put into one menu you have to click your way through- Abilities are really the boring standard cyberpunk arsenal, nothing that is even remotely interesting or new (hacking, drones, for hacker class, tank ability and berserk mode for soldier, field heal and squad buffs for support, melee and cloak for infiltrator)- Cannot save when you actually need it, no quicksave (in enemy tarrain not even out of combat)- Unclear what actions award what quantities of EXP, many things are not well enough explainedI can recommend this game, however it would have been nice if more interesting stuff would be added and the menus need a clear rework. Apart from that I had fun with the game and it kept me interested, I can say I do not regret buying it and it is worth its money.I will update this review as additions or patches will get released.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 11, 2015
												FInal Verdict-Finished game. PLUS THE ONE MAJOR FLAWProbably a lot of people bought the game because it reminds them on syndicate, and it truly gives off that feeling.It's a great game, let's get that out of the way. Sure the pathfinding at first is a pain, but after a few hours you will understand it. The game does lack a story line, but like most cyber punk stories, big biz runs things so you can fill in the gaps.The game has an awsome idea, you have four clones who each have a role. A soilder, support, hacker, and infiltrator which I'll get into detail about the roles at the end of this. Your hacker can hijack people who have better stats and send them back to be cloned, so you can switch into their bodies...Or you can form a little army and make them follow you and fight with you. Game play is what it's all about. This is where it may lose some people. You are tough but the baddies are as well, it's like not like you can have 2 hold a choke point,  while two other clones go ahead because you will get beat down.  There is very little out flanking moments because generally it feels like you all have to aim at the same baddie at once. Plus since it's point and click as well as a far number of keyboard commands which are a mess because the button (G) stands for your bombs, but more than one clone might have bombs. It's possible to do flaking when you have a small little army with you, but everyone you hijack is labled as number 5 in response to keyboard button control. You can go into a combat zone and say this is group one and group two because if you hit "1" or "2" it will just select one of your clones.So in other words, your fighting in a cluster. I'm not sure if this is meant to be like this, but I don't think it is due to the roles of your clones. Your support clone even can slow down time to get people to a different location but your energy level goes down really fast. Which is anothe flaw with the game, even running takes away your energy fast, faster than any ability. In the end I really enjoyed it stil, I hope there is a DLC.------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Roles of your ClonesSolider: No heavy weapon penality-though they don't come in till mid-to late game. He has a few abilities where he can take or give more damage but the energy depeletes so fast you bearly will use it.  He can hardwire generators and turn gas pipes. Support. Basically your healer but he can scan for targets and read peoples stats. Other than that he is just sort of there as another gun.Hacker: Probably your most usable character. He can hijack soilders and people to either fight with you or send them back to clone. Of course he can shut down systems and take control over doors. He also has drones. Much of the time he will be running around hijacking people. infiltrator: Sort of like your theif/sniper. The clone can clock which doesn't last long, and the sword ability can kill with one thrust, yet again you run into recharge time and energy issues. They can also sneak into places, which you can augment your other players to do so as well.Since there is a gizmo called a hacker proxy, basically this clone becomes important because the clone doesn't have to equip the stealth generator and your hacker generally has almost no energy because he is controlling hijack soilders. They can sneak in and turn off cameras. The sniper riffle is powerful but very slow, you don't have to use it, there are only two sniper rifles in the whole game, but using it does give you some special abilities

content:
Posted: April 24
												It's just not very good. I tried to like it. I slogged through the whole thing, but it's just sort of empty and soulless.First off: preformance is just terrible. Even on minimum with a 3770K and a 980ti I get about 40 FPS at 1080. During the course of play, it slowly drops down to sub 20. It's just not acceptable considering how ugly the game can be.The mechanics are... meh. A lack of auto-return fire means sometimes you'll have a dummy who's not fighting back because of the really bad AI. Your guys will get stuck on things constantly, often getting blown to pieces while you try to figure out how to free them. Research is sort of weird, and honestly I could never really care to dive into it.I had no attachment to my agents. Upgrading the clones was a tiresome chore where you hunt through the city, try to abduct a civilian/solider, and then hope you don't set off an alarm. If you do, you'll be forced to run around town, Benny Hill style, until you lose them or run off to a safe point. You'll do this a lot to upgrade your guys, but you'll also be doing a lot of the same 5 or 6 or so activities through the city about 90 times each.I can't even speak about the story because it was pretty much conveyed by a British woman that was hard to hear during all the gunfire/etc.I wanted to like it. It's cyberpunk. It's just not very good.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 14, 2016
												Loved this GAME! I'm huge fan of Shadowrun, but this was ever better.Game give you lots of options for solving problems:If your breaking into a facility and there are cameras you can solve this in a variety of ways; sneak around them, cut the power, hack in and put them on a loop, or just shoot them with your gun. This is just one of many examples of how the game lets you change the way you approach different missions. You can post a sniper and clear the area or just detonate the door and go in guns blazing. Or maybe hack the brains of the enemy soldier so they start fighting each other as a distraction, or have them join you and start building an army to clear the place out with (I always found that to be the slowest method since reinforcements are endless).There is a lot of mission variety too. Stealing: prototypes, information, money. Rescue. Assainate. Sneak in a spy. Hack in to their network. Even as you approach the mission you can take the bruteforce method or gather intel: pay off a disgruntled employee or do a few favor for them to make the job easier.

												While I ams preparing for final infiltration to DG tower and, I have to drop a few words here. When I heard during the KS that someone is going to re-create the Syndicate...or better...create game that would look like, feellike and play like Syndicate, I was like...Whoy. Shut up and take my money!Waiting for the game, waiting for every new piece of information, backer update etdc...I was patient. When beta was out, Ive tried a few minutes, maybe hours, and thought...well this is looking good, Ill wait for the final. And once final was out...I have 71 hours in the game now, if I can trust Steam, and it was time of pure pleasure and fun. The game didnt try to amuse me. It allowed me to amuse myself. Playground and toys are all at players disposal, the way he chooses to use them is up to us. I was wandering around those four districts, and after finishing nicely prepared missioopns I have repeatedly infiltrated oponent bases, making fun of those, dehonesting them,♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥them in their houses and in their most private moments.Because that is what the game feels like. It is terrible, brutal and inhuman/transhuma/posthuman world, where you can sntch mans body and puppetmaster him to the grave, and once he is of no use, you throw him away. Bussiness is build on this, religion is built on this, and possibly even immortality of those in power. And you are nothinhg like savior of the world. To compete those ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s, you act exactly the same way, doing whatever it takes to get the job done. Syndicate was mess. This is ultra. One can sy, that the game lacks the blood...I say it doesnt need it. Plasma burns dont bleed.Variety of playstyles is IMO overhelmming. From silent individual infiltration, well coordinated team operation to heavy weapons assault with rockets and plasmaballs flying everywhere. Silencers, Katanas, machine guns, laser minigiuns, suicidal bombers...hell it is a ride to hgell and back again. Multiple times.I certeinly hope 5 Lives take this as a start to continue in the same...or better...kind of production to the future. Because the game is simply brilliant. See you on the Bullfrog bridge whemn I am done with the tower, and we will discuss what else. In case it is all a set up and I wont make it back, good work guys.

content:
Posted: August 28, 2015
												Satellite Reign is a modern take on Syndicate Wars. You control a team of agents that complete various missions in real-time squad-based tactical combat and stealth. If you like this kind of game there's not a lot of options out there and Satellite Reign is a good entry into the genre. Check out gameplay from the release version on PC (ultra settings) here:

												To claim this is the 'spiritual successor' of Syndicate is a dishonour and an outright lie, shame on 5 lives studios.No drivable cars, no environmental destruction, no 'weird/crazy' weapons/gadgets like Syndicate, semi personalised characters, no world/corporate domonation... group feels like petty armed thugs running around the 'dead' streets killing and stealing with no purpose, not some organised, professional group fighting for or bringing down mega corps working from some secret base/HQ/whatever (I think my 'agents' live on the street, I mean you couldn't assume anything else as there is no home base).... it feels pointless and without meaning.- AI both NPC and character AI is horrible and frustrating.- Bugs, glitches and poor performance.... still today (2016)- Weapons are boring and simple and seriously lack diversity... no strange and weird weapons like Syndicate or SW and weapon attachments are no subsitute for the weird and awesome weapons of the originals- Augmentations are weak and boring in terms of diversity/types.- No tactical pause, which is needed with terrible AI pathfinding and no combat mode/stance.- Cities feel hollow and dead, things move around but its no living city.- The environment is beautiful- Cannot configure my agents as they have 'personality', clones/agent are meant to be a base/stock unit I can configure and build how I like but they are pre-defined archetypes I can only slightly modify them from whats forced... imo ruins the whoile idea- Backers still haven't received the physical rewards.- Game world looks beautiful, but then so does thief2014.... both are boring lackluster game.Please devs, stop ruining classics by remaking shallow, boring junk... if you're not going to do it properly f'k off.... a remake of Syndicate/SW with the tech and knowledge of 20 years should have been a master piece, a classic.... sadly into just another bad remake in a long list of bad, money grabbing remakes....

number of helpful: 16 of 30 people (53%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 30, 2015
												Don't know what to say here; I've played this for a few hours and encountered nothing but annoying bug after irritating glitch. I've lost at least an hour to autosaves that didn't actually save, being forced to reload half way through a successful stealth through a compound because a drone glitched out on a set of stairs that happened to be the only way to continue through the level, AI that can 'wall-hack' and spot you half way across the map behind cover for no apparent reason, etc, etc. For every two steps forward I made, the game forced me to take one step back because of the lack of polish. I could forgive it if it was me making the mistakes but in almost every case it wasn't.Combat is boring and ridiculously simplistic. Don't expect the AI to do anything more than stand in the open and spray bullets at you until people start dying. There's no skill, tactics, or strategy required here and it's pretty disappointing. Some mechanics simply don't make sense at all. You need a skill to use a zipline? Seriously? I've got a belt and two hands that will let me use any zipline I ever wanna use. Who thought this was a clever idea?The tutorial in some parts just flat out forget to mention some game mechanics - to warn others, when the game teaches you how to hijack people, your target's under a camera. Thanks for letting us know that cameras can somehow see a person getting hijacked! Then shoving the console for turning them off half way across the map. Wait, the guy that needs to hack the console is also the guy that needs to hijack the person? Aye yai yai. This game has potential but it needs quite a bit more work. Based off the experience I've had with it so far, I simply can't recommend it to others at this time.Edit: So after several patches, I decided to come back to this game and see if it's any better. I've made it to the final area of the game and completed most of the missions in the game in all the prior districts. So reading this, you must think, it's a lot better now, right? No. I'm not going to bother finishing this game. My characters are more powerful, they have great gear and I'm quite used to the game play and all the glitches that can and will happen throughout a mission but that doesn't mean this has been much of a fun experience. It's the little glitches and jank that add up. For example, I missed out on the entering CBD peacefully achievement after going through the giant mess to get the cards you need to enter because when my guys went into the second scanning room, the entering door closed first instead of the exit door and blocked three of my four guys from going inside the room. So what did the AI do? It decided to go around the door and right into the restricted zone where everything turns hostile the moment you go into it. I had no control over this, it happened within a second. Great. Thanks, a little bug/oversight and all that hard work gone to♥♥♥♥♥♥ I suppose I could have reloaded a save but you know what? I'm tired of doing that. I had to do that constantly just to play this game to deal with all its little problems and issues and it was the final straw. I could give example after example after example of all the little problems like that but it doesn't matter.The devil is in the details and it's a measure of the quality of the game. This game is rife with small issues galore and it's massively disappointing. So 20 hours in and a few hours away from finishing the game, I give up and wave the white flag. And to think that instead of fixing up their game they're adding co-op to it to further compound the amount of stuff that could go wrong. Yikes.

content:
Posted: September 10, 2015
												This is definitely a worthy spiritual successor to Syndicate Wars. The cyberpunk setting and art are beautifully presented and the squad based action gameplay is solid. Running amok in a dystopian future run by greedy megacorporations, dishing out countless violent deaths with an arsenal of weapons at the hands of my cybernetically altered agents, while carving out my own place in this world..what more could you want from a game. I would have preferred a classless game with agents totally customizable (including an option to wear the classic trenchcoats from Syndicate) instead of the specific agent designs. Another thing I noticed was I quickly acquired plasma weapons, before even getting the prototypes for the ballistic weapons and other gear, which made alot of it seem pointless. Seeing references to Bullfrog in the game was also pretty cool and gave me nostalgic memories from the golden age of PC gaming. A fair priced game worth checking out if you have played the older games, or even if you're a fan of squad based strategy games. Look forward to seeing what 5live do next.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 26, 2016
												This game definitely needs a bit of polish, and the areas that do need polish definitely show, but overall it is an amazing game. The tag strategy is a bit misleading, since it has as much "strategy" as Far Cry 3 does. This doesn't mean that planning an attack is unnecessary, since the player can easily get outnumbered and gunned down if they are not careful.The music and aesthetic are amazing. The sound design is spot on, and generally the game is truly immersive. Not in the sense of story or plot, since most of the backstory for the missions are text based, and most of the plot takes a backseat to the action. As stated before, the gameplay is great. The fire fights can get pretty intense, and the stealth mechanics (using cover, cloaking, hacking, and hardwiring) are awesome as well. Cover provides defensive bonuses, and most cover is destructable, making late game fire fights even more hectic. As it says in the trailer, it is open world, meaning you can approach a compound however you want. There are some balance issues, such as minor weapon imbalances, being able to replace single use items (grenades, etc) with an infinite- use ammo box, and the proxy hacker.Now for the bad parts. I saved this section for later in the review, since it shouldn't disincentivise someone from getting the game. NPCs and player controlled characters sometimes get stuck on the map geometry, the cover system can be difficult to work with, and teammates may randomly become slower or faster, regardless of equipment.I'm not good at writing conclusions, but if I were to recommend this game, I would recomend it to someone who wants to get into real time strategy, but normally finds them boring. It is an intense yet easy game to get behind, and definitely worth playing. To be honest, this game isn't worth 32.99- I would say it is more worth 20 bucks, but that is just me. Definitely buy it when it goes on sale. If I were to give it a rating out of 100, I would say it gets a solid 78 out of 100.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 30, 2016
												Syndicate Wars reborn, and the closest you'll get to open world coop Shadow Run.This game is amazing, it's everything I wanted and more.  When I was in highschool I'd play Syndicate Wars with my friends.  We'd plan out intricate hits on corporations, brain wash groups of civilians, and cause tons of cyberpunk mayhem.  Satellite Reign is that plus more.  It's a sandboxed world, and at many turns feels like the original Deus Ex but multiplayer coop (which I've always dreamed of).  The classes are unique and balanced, and as your characters grow you go from feeling like you have no power to completely over powered (which is incredibly awesome when you're wiping out a wave of troopers responding to an alarm and blowing up giant turrets).Another interesting component, I picked this up with my friend that played Syndicate Wars back in the day.  Slowly, our other friends that enjoy cyberpunk and Shadow Run, would watch our stream and start buying the game.  We're about 5 people deep now, and each person's game (you can drop in drop out) has a different progression of technology.  In mine, we have fully augmented bodies, in my friends we have high powered machine pistols and plasma rifles.If you liked anyone of these games this is for you: X-Com, Syndicate, Alien Swarm, Shadow Run, basically any tactical game.The only con I've found so far on the game is in the UI department.  But that's been pretty easy to navigate once you understand the nuances.

content:
Posted: July 30, 2016
												I have waited so long for a Syndicate Wars successor to come out and this one nails it! Research cyber augmentations, weapons, and gear to enhance your clones and deploy them around the open city with the goal of penetrating enemy corporations strongholds to steal more weapons, gear, and aug plans. You can hack ATMs to slowly siphon money from them, bribe researchers on the street to work for you and guards to give you information or forget your crimes, and hardwire doors shut so that enemies can't get through. They even kept a type of "indoctrinator" mechanic from Syndicate Wars, only they call it "Hijacking".All in all, I would highly recommend this game, especially with a friend. With each player having two runners the game feels very well balanced. I hope the devs continue developing this game and in the process continue raising the bar on coop tactical combat.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2016
												I doubt there are too many reviews of SR out there that dont, at some point, reference the classic game The Syndicate, so there, I'm getting it out of the way early. A lot of the play is along those lines, except in a persistent, semi-open world environment. And that's a good thing! It takes that old atmosphere and modernizes it very well, while adding in a somewhat more freeform gameplay style. The ability to affect the environment (cameras, doors, etc) definitely adds a lot of interesting possibilities to a given run.So if pointy-clicky strategy games or strong cyberpunk environments are your jam, I recommend it. That's not to say it's perfect. I'd definitely have to say that it gets repetetive after a while. I also wish the story was much more fleshed out. There's a lot of potential for storytelling here, but even with the included novella it seems somewhat thin. And as a consequence of that, now and then I found myself getting into that mentality of "wait, why am I doing this mission again? Does this one matter or is it just for resources?" Still, I definitely enjoy it. And although I didn't get it on it back when it was a Kickstarter, I'd hold it up as a success for crowdfunding in general.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								   As many reviews have stated this is what the Syndicate reboot should have been.  That being said, for a pre alpha the game shows lots and lots of promise.  I played for almost an hour as of the writing of this review and it is painful to tear myself away because I have work in the morning.      I was expecting a lot of nonsense that didn't make sense, with little or no intuitive gui and a glitch ridden experince that I *might* think about playing if they put several more months of work into it... you know the standard early release.     What I got was a well put together alpha that made lots of sense, has a great minimalistic gui and delivers a good game experience (for an alpha).   Are there glitches?  Sure.  Can I get in a car an play destination roulette while flying through barricades?  Sure.   ...but in an alpha those glitches are good glitches that make fun anecdotes and often lead to interesting things the developers didnt expect.  The core gameplay (run, cover, shoot, kill, complete) worked great.  I had some issues picking up new weapons at first but I learned that: 1. double click and 2. if at first you don't succeed try again   Other comments....  The environment is good.  Dark, Futuristic, Dystopian but not dysmal.   Lots of intrigue and places to explore.  Performance is good, I have everything cranked up and am using my DSR on my Nvidia to run at 1.5x native.    Combat seems pretty good, the AI was sharp enough to flank me and seek superior cover and setup interlocking fields of fire. (...or maybe my bots got lucky and I got over excited...  I mean one cop did freak out and try to run back into the police station even though the door was closed so I might be assigning too much credit...  So the Devs may have to confirm that one.)   All in all very, very excited to see how this game developes!!!  Can't wait to finish the existing material.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								EARLY ACCESS REVIEW, 25th April 2015:I purchased this the other day purely because I was delighted to find that someone was creating it (It had gone completely unnoticed by me up until that point).I loved Syndicate and Syndicate Wars, so I was very excited when I came across this.I bought it to support the developers and help ensure that this becomes what I hope it will be, and a part of me was curious enough to want to see what they have done with it so far.In its current state the game is definitely playable (and visually very cool if you like that cyberpunk feel, as others have said) but I think all you'll get from it right now is a feel for the environment you're going to play in and some of the basic mechanics. I've played it for a couple of hours now, but found it got tedious very quickly - I wouldn't recommend buying at this stage *IF* you're hoping for something you can already get your teeth into.You start straight into the tutorial which teaches you the very basics, and are then left standing in the city with little idea of what to do next.There are a few missions accessible through what I'd call the map screen which seems to be playing the role of the in game menu, with tabs for research, missions, system, etc. - It's pretty naff but it allows you to do what you need to do which I'm sure serves the purpose of the early access release. I'm sure the UI will be developed further.There's no sense of purpose yet which is the only reason I got bored so quickly, and I'll probably refrain from playing any further until the game is either much further along in development or actually released.Really excited about playing it again when it's finished, or at least once the aforementioned lack of any sense of why you're there, why you've got beef with the other groups, why should you infiltrate that facility etc. has been rectified - as someone else said in a review, story is important! Openworld / non-linear can be great, but you still need a sense of purpose or you're just working through a mundane list in a menu.Some kind of background story should also give you some context as to what is right and wrong in this world - Does murdering innocents carry any real consequence other than a few police showing up? Does killing the police mean anything more than a flashing exclamation mark in a box and perhaps a couple more police showing up? You get the point.Overall, would I recommend buying it? When it's finished, if it becomes what it's shaping up to be: YES!Is it fun to play right now at this stage? Not really - I would only recommend buying right now if you want to support the devs like I do, or actually get involved in the development process (which of course is the purpose of Early Access).

content:
Posted: March 18, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game looks like it has alot of potential once its completed, currently it is a very nice showing of their engine and a small taste of their game. But with time this game looks like it will be one amazing cyberpunk game. On a gameplay note I love how they are implementing a stealth system into a RTS style game. Currently they have a few missions and a weak AI.but as said this is still in Pre-Alpha so they are just giving us a little taste of whats to come, and I cant wait. An example story of a fun little expensure I had is below:"Early On you have to sneak past some guards in order to open a gate, and get to downtown. In order to do so I ran my hacker to hack the security cam and turn it off, after that I got my soldier to run into cover while a guard was looking. The guard slowly started to move over to investigate finding my soldier "hiding" immediately he started walking him away hands above his head. This allowed me to run my other man to the door and my hacker to open the door. Once the door was opened I ran my soldier away from the guard and over to the opened door... Sadly, the guard didnt put up any fight, he didnt try to shoot me or even chase me that fast. Let alone open the closed door with a keycard or passcode. But then again, this game is still in Pre-Alpha so the AI is obviously going to be a bit weak as said.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 24, 2015
Early Access Review
								   As many reviews have stated this is what the Syndicate reboot should have been.  That being said, for a pre alpha the game shows lots and lots of promise.  I played for almost an hour as of the writing of this review and it is painful to tear myself away because I have work in the morning.      I was expecting a lot of nonsense that didn't make sense, with little or no intuitive gui and a glitch ridden experince that I *might* think about playing if they put several more months of work into it... you know the standard early release.     What I got was a well put together alpha that made lots of sense, has a great minimalistic gui and delivers a good game experience (for an alpha).   Are there glitches?  Sure.  Can I get in a car an play destination roulette while flying through barricades?  Sure.   ...but in an alpha those glitches are good glitches that make fun anecdotes and often lead to interesting things the developers didnt expect.  The core gameplay (run, cover, shoot, kill, complete) worked great.  I had some issues picking up new weapons at first but I learned that: 1. double click and 2. if at first you don't succeed try again   Other comments....  The environment is good.  Dark, Futuristic, Dystopian but not dysmal.   Lots of intrigue and places to explore.  Performance is good, I have everything cranked up and am using my DSR on my Nvidia to run at 1.5x native.    Combat seems pretty good, the AI was sharp enough to flank me and seek superior cover and setup interlocking fields of fire. (...or maybe my bots got lucky and I got over excited...  I mean one cop did freak out and try to run back into the police station even though the door was closed so I might be assigning too much credit...  So the Devs may have to confirm that one.)   All in all very, very excited to see how this game developes!!!  Can't wait to finish the existing material.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								Syn.. Satellite reign.. mm.. yes. Screw EA's remake of the oldschool game syndicate. We don't want no fps we want remake best. Amiga.. old PC. syndicate. That awesome game that comes to mind when you watch this games details. IF you have played that. It actually, this game called satellite reign, exceeded my expectations. It had all i could have possibly hoped for to resurrect my old memories of my beloved oldschool game syndicate. You get it ALL. your 4 player squad, your corporation, your minigun, your personalised squad, your clones, your augmentations, your cyberpunk minicity to roam in, your cool cute tiny futuristic vehicles, your special missions, your tactical sense and radar signals of objectives and THEN some !ok.. if you rush.. you might most likely die. which is a good thing. this game is something i've missed since the 90s. and with great graphics, concept and gameplay even if alpha. i salute the indie developer. THANK YOU ! from the bottom of my heart. This game might not "be your thing" but if you think of elite dangerous as a great remake of elite plus back in the day. then satellite reign is an awesome reincarnation of the closest possible thing to syndicate plus from our cherished memories of kickass games from back in the day. Haven't played that much yet but enough to be able to make this review. Thanks for reading. 8/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2015
 Satellite Reign  Hobo Assault   Genre Open World Squad Based Stealth Tactical RTS   Plays Like Syndicate, Star Trek Away Team, Dawn of War 2   Positive   True to the root genre.  Challenging. Interesting if underdeveloped cloning system.    Negative   Long load times. Lack of feedback on enemy vision cones or audible detection. Poor performance.    Recommendation Yes. Another great genre has been resurrected. Satellite Reign is the crowd funded spiritual successor to 1993's Syndicate by Bullfrog and Ocean Software. That's quite the pairing of companies, which makes me sad that I never played Syndicate, because from my research, I'm sure I would have loved it. I have however played other games in the genre, so I am at least familiar enough with Satellite Reign's roots. SR is a tactical RTS set in a dystopian future à la Perfect Dark, where city services are privately owned and PMC soldiers roam the streets with assault rifles and drones. You control a specialised 4 man squad of terrorists as they roam the city, destabilise the PMCs, rob banks and kidnap hobos.The game drops you into a tutorial sequence that teaches you the basics. Just the basics. A lot of what happens in this game, you're going to have to work out from experience, because the only place you're going to get information after the tutorial is in the quest log. It's not too bad as long as you have a modicum of common sense, but it would be nice to see some of the features expanded on. The cloning aspect of the game for example is only mentioned in vague terms. When a soldier dies, their consciousness is transferred to a clone which degrades each time the process occurs. You can hijack anyone's neural implants to control them and send them back to base to add to your pool of clones. What I would have liked to have seen is some mechanic where you can combine the genes of 2 clones to create a new source clone. As it is, cloning is just an inconvenience meant to give you some way to maintain your soldiers. The hijacking mechanic has other interesting uses though. I had to infiltrate a shipping yard, so I scoured the backstreets for as many hobos as I could control and sent them on a suicide assault at the front of the base while my squad slipped by unnoticed. Moments like that are memorable, and it's great to see a game that gives you the freedom to think outside the box. Also featured is a prototype research system. When you successfully complete a mission, you will probably steal a prototype. This can be a weapon, gear or implant. Your soldiers can equip the loot, but if you research it, you will be able to mass produce the item. I like this system. It reminds me of XCOM's method of loot progression. Like XCOM, you recruit scientists to research your prototypes. The early researches take about 15 minutes of real time to complete and will constantly drain your funds while it happens. Partnered with this mechanic is the ATM siphon mechanic. You can rob a bank for a one time large sum of money, but the bulk of your income will come from the ATMs around the world that you physically go to and install a siphon virus onto. Most will give you around 20c per second, a rate that can be improved by infiltrating a bank with your hacker. This small trickle of funds means that your researches have to be prioritised. Thats a nice, organic way to involve the player in what I call "budgetting strategy". Both systems work well together and provide the backbone for the progression throughout the game. The game looks great, despite its modest download size. The aesthetic is the same classic cyberpunk that we've come to expect since Blade Runner. Lots of neon decorate the streets and the people who populate the world have crazy hair, tatoos and sci fi sunglasses. It's pretty great. What isn't great however is the performance of the game. I have a decent system which sufficed to say should have no issue with this game, but unfortunately I couldn't seem to get more than about 40fps on a regular basis. I was having a blast with the game, but it's a shame that I didn't have the most responsive experience given that the game is largely about precision in execution. Of course, with many technical issues, your mileage may vary, so just be aware that you may also encounter less than optimal performance.The soundtrack in my opinion is serviceable, providing the appropriate cyberpunk techno that you would expect with just a dash of 80's sci fi thrown in for a bit of character. There aren't really any memorable tunes here, but the soundtrack may serve as ambient sci fi music if you have use for that sort of thing elsewhere. I found it decent enough to add to my board game playlist. The soundtrack is available in both mp3 and flac formats.I really liked this game. It's great to see genres returning via crowdfunding that wouldn't otherwise be produced. Satellite Reign is a competent tactical RTS that held my attention for hours and probably one that I will want to replay at some point. It's a nice mix of genres that satisfies several itches, whether you want stealth, tactical firefights or hobo assaults. Highly recommended to fans of the genre who want something new.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 26, 2016
												This game definitely needs a bit of polish, and the areas that do need polish definitely show, but overall it is an amazing game. The tag strategy is a bit misleading, since it has as much "strategy" as Far Cry 3 does. This doesn't mean that planning an attack is unnecessary, since the player can easily get outnumbered and gunned down if they are not careful.The music and aesthetic are amazing. The sound design is spot on, and generally the game is truly immersive. Not in the sense of story or plot, since most of the backstory for the missions are text based, and most of the plot takes a backseat to the action. As stated before, the gameplay is great. The fire fights can get pretty intense, and the stealth mechanics (using cover, cloaking, hacking, and hardwiring) are awesome as well. Cover provides defensive bonuses, and most cover is destructable, making late game fire fights even more hectic. As it says in the trailer, it is open world, meaning you can approach a compound however you want. There are some balance issues, such as minor weapon imbalances, being able to replace single use items (grenades, etc) with an infinite- use ammo box, and the proxy hacker.Now for the bad parts. I saved this section for later in the review, since it shouldn't disincentivise someone from getting the game. NPCs and player controlled characters sometimes get stuck on the map geometry, the cover system can be difficult to work with, and teammates may randomly become slower or faster, regardless of equipment.I'm not good at writing conclusions, but if I were to recommend this game, I would recomend it to someone who wants to get into real time strategy, but normally finds them boring. It is an intense yet easy game to get behind, and definitely worth playing. To be honest, this game isn't worth 32.99- I would say it is more worth 20 bucks, but that is just me. Definitely buy it when it goes on sale. If I were to give it a rating out of 100, I would say it gets a solid 78 out of 100.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								Syn.. Satellite reign.. mm.. yes. Screw EA's remake of the oldschool game syndicate. We don't want no fps we want remake best. Amiga.. old PC. syndicate. That awesome game that comes to mind when you watch this games details. IF you have played that. It actually, this game called satellite reign, exceeded my expectations. It had all i could have possibly hoped for to resurrect my old memories of my beloved oldschool game syndicate. You get it ALL. your 4 player squad, your corporation, your minigun, your personalised squad, your clones, your augmentations, your cyberpunk minicity to roam in, your cool cute tiny futuristic vehicles, your special missions, your tactical sense and radar signals of objectives and THEN some !ok.. if you rush.. you might most likely die. which is a good thing. this game is something i've missed since the 90s. and with great graphics, concept and gameplay even if alpha. i salute the indie developer. THANK YOU ! from the bottom of my heart. This game might not "be your thing" but if you think of elite dangerous as a great remake of elite plus back in the day. then satellite reign is an awesome reincarnation of the closest possible thing to syndicate plus from our cherished memories of kickass games from back in the day. Haven't played that much yet but enough to be able to make this review. Thanks for reading. 8/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 3, 2016
												It was one of those very promising early access projects that actually delivered later on, and I bought it at it's relase. Sadly, at this point the game had severe crashing issues up to the point where it was unenjoyable because of the crashes occuring every 10 to 15 minutes.A year later, the game has been patched up nicely, I was able to play 5+ hours without any technical issues, so the real game finally started to flourish. I'll do a quick listing type of review on this one:What are you getting Atmosphere: Ghost in the Shell and Deus Ex just had a baby who likes to play Commandos and XCOM. Loads of written information, background lore, severe lack of voiceacting (nobody speaks but the mission info reading women).  Surface: extremely good looking visuals both technically and designwise, good music if you are into 80's retro electro effects and overall wibe (check Dynatron, Magnatron, NewRetroWave on YouTube). Gameplay: team coordinating Commandos-like gameplay with a cover system in an open world (city devided to districts), you go whereever and whenver you like, if you are good enough. Mistakes are harshly punished, but there is a safety net to fall back on and start over. Several layers of character customization (not so much visually), skills, equipment, core body stats, upgrading choices having real serious impact on gameplay. Somebody may use a zipline to get in to a fortress, or you upgraded cloaking instead and have to take an entirely different route, always keeping in mind that you have to work with 4 disctinct characters. Playtime: 6 hours in I'm about halfway done with the first district of the city. I expect at least 3, more like 4-5 disctricts. You are taking over the industry, so if that has as much thought behind it as the rest of the design choices, it's definitly not going to be just 2 or 3 districts.Positives+ Atmosphere, graphics and music.+ Surprisingly deep gameplay features (bribing, information gathering, finances, stealth, the networking of the city and how we take advantage of it).+ Decent playtime, filled up with interesting, really challanging gameplay backed up with excellent world building.+ Well supported by the developers (cooperative multiplayer got added much later for free).Negatives- Gameplay features such as kidnapping and bribing also show the lack of other features (such as being able to try to bribe anyone with a chance of failure and alert, instead of bribe = always works, and you can do it only with certain people, not any guard or citizen to create a disctraction for example). People feel like assets and throwaway tools, and while the story is literally exactly this, it feels wrong on the user side for all the wrong reasons (see below), instead of fulfilling this story.- Only one character has voiceover, and the game is REALLY silent. There are no smalltalk chatter on the streets filled with dozens of people, the floating cars make no noise at all, far more than often you only hear your footsteps in a busy city.Should you get it?10 / If you like retro-neon style injected into modern cyberpunk done well, stealth oriented gameplay and RPG elements with the freedom of choice about what to do and how to do it, I can recommend this game for you. If you are specificly interested in this game, give it a shot somewhat below 20 euros, it won't disappoint. If you are interested in the setting / atmosphere, you want to wait for a much deeper discount (9,99-12,99) and look for other cyberpunk titles in the meantime.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2015
												I spent the first hour stumbling around, confused by the game world, fighting the slightly clunky (Unity 5) interface, and remapping all the keybinds.  "Pah!", I thought, "I guess this game's not for me!"But then I found that couldn't stop thinking about the game for the next couple days; the immersive game world, deep character customization, and heart-racing heists had drawn me in.  After another hour or two of figuring out what I was doing, I really started to love the game.  Highly, HIGHLY recommended. P.S.: If you like cyberpunk and RPGs, don't be put off by the fact that it's in real time!  You get the ability to slow down time considerably, and while you may fail miserably and get your entire team killed early on, the consequences of death are rather minimal.  You'll get better!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23, 2016
												I really wanted to like this game. I loved Syndicate Wars. It is one of my favorite games on Playstation. Unfortunately, Satellite Reign is nowhere near as good. This game has potential, but it will not be reached until Satellite Reign II, if that ever comes out.The thing I absolutely hated in Satellite Reign is mouse controls. The agents feel unresponsive sometimes, certain actions are very hard to get to activate at maximum camera height. It's also hard to get the agents to stand exactly where you need for the same reasons. Overall, the controls feel laggy and not precise enough. This makes the game unplayable at times thanks to the fact that it is real-time. I was struggling to control my agents and get them to do exactly what I wanted them to in fights where more than two enemies were involved. Then there's the fact that the game doesn't save your location or certain game state elements. When you reload a saved game it simply places your agents at the neares respawn location. Basically, you can't try a certain approach and when it doesn't work just reload and try again. You'll have to run back from the damn spawn point, get all agents into positions, wait for the enemies to move into their positions... Basically, the game actively punishes you for reloading and tries to force you to live with the consequences of failed actions.This could work for you, but it doesn't for me. I could ignore this if the rest of the game was tight, but it's just not.Enemies keep respawning almost instantly if you take them out silently, makes clearing compounds stealthily to try and make a path for your Hacker completely pointless. It all boils down to two approaches: sneak past all the security cameras and guards or fight your way to the objective and back. If at least the missions had a bit more variety to them, but most of the missions in the first grid are just the same routine over and over again with nothing to do between them except for trying to get better clones. Unless you're REALLY into Syndicate and want something to scratch that itch, go ahead and grab Satellite Reign. Otherwise, I don't recommend it.

												This a fantastic game. Balancing strategy, timing and going ham/balls to the wall. It offers mutliple ways to succeed in any mission depending on how you are choosing to play. This flexibility isn't just limited to how to how you skill your team but can be changed between missons by switching equipped Augemntations and Gear. Something that has left me very satisfied when I had to run away from some seriously heavy firefights and came back with my heavy hitting Augments. It is simple and addictive. I would write more but I have to go inflitrate a top security facilityto get me some bigger guns.

content:
Posted: January 6
												If you've ever played the card game Android: Netrunner and want a real-time, singleplayer (or co-op) version of it where you play as the runners, here you go.This is not a stealth game like Commandos or Shadow Tactics, if you try to stealth through everything you're going to get frustrated. This is a game about staying hidden until the right moment and getting your squad into position before taking out the generator with a grenade from your cloaked infiltrator so that your soldier and support can zipline in from a nearby rooftop while the cameras are down and security is tied up at the generator, then hacking into the commander's mind and opening fire on his minions while your soldier lays down a hail of plasma and your support unleashes nanobots to heal and the distraction ties up the garrison long enough for your hacker to steal the important files AND for your infiltrator to hit the bank vault and walk out with a money sack.And it's good at that.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 31, 2015
												Well, I purchased this game back in April, just to support the devs. Now that it's released, I decided to go for a full playthrough. EASILY one of the best games I've ever played. Nevermind entirely topping the genre. All four of the character types have very individual skill focuses, but the whole team is needed to complete most of the missions. The ones that don't require everybody are even more fun than they would have been because you get the feeling of rarity in focusing on one or two characters every once in awhile.The enhancement and gear system is AMAZING, giving you the option to give up stat enhancements in order to add extra abilities that the character normally wouldn't have access to. The "research/prototype" system is a GREAT balance of risk vs. patience. The missions in each area gradually increase in difficulty and do force the player to think more as the game progresses.This game is by no means perfect, as the visual customisation is very limited for characters, the doors and NPCs will sometimes bug and mess something up, and the player character movement is definitely not flawless. However, this team of devs has worked ASTONISHINGLY hard to fix as much as possible, as quickly as possible, and hasn't skipped a beat with the official release. Truly one of the best dev teams I've ever personally experienced. They deserve so much credit.TL:DR/Final comments: When all is said and done, if you like a game that allows you total freedom to choose how to accomplish things, requires constant teamwork between all of your controlled NPCs, has a fun reward/loot system with LOTS of possibilities, has gorgeous graphics, and will make you think and pay close attention, this game is a MUST have. Also, if you played/loved the original Syndicate, just go ahead and buy it. There's no way you won't appreciate it.

Posted: July 10, 2016
												Didn't finish the game yet, I imagine I'm 25% in after 12 hours. So it obviously is lengthy. I did everything there is to do in the first sector, though.I'd consider this game as a mixture of Syndicate and Commando, a real time tactical shooter with heavy stealth elements.You can interrupt circuits, hack doors, bribe officials, cut power, destroy cameras, steal access codes and hack drones to get your task done. Varied approached are valid and yield results.I really recommend it.You need some patience,  but it's nothing compared to e.g. the commando series. Also it's not really punishing if you screw up. You don't lose more than a few minutes of progress.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2016
												Pros-The levels are really fun to play -It has a pretty good progression mechanic-The art is great-Soundtrack is decent-Gives you many options and ways to attack a compound which is really fun to experiment with-Has alot of little side quest per areaCons-Story isn't too interesting-Has annoying bugs that, while not game-breaking, can mess up the mission and some rare ones make you have to restart the game-The levels get super easy at around 60% of the game if you just equip your agents with proxy hacker and stealth generators and the missions don't adjust to itI recommend it if you like tactical strategy games, 'cause this one is pretty solid 7.5/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 5, 2015
												Pros: almost everything.Have not quite reached the end yet, but so far this has been a deep game with many systems and features, an open world, multiple ways to approach a problem, good writing, good cyberpunk graphics and sound design, and good value for money.Cons: There are two big cons. The first is the AI, specificlally the AI pathfinding. It can get infuriating when your team gets stuck on geometry when you only have a one second window to move them into cover. An enemy team can also get stuck near an entrance you need to access. A shame really.The other big problem is that the game gets repetitive after a while. There are 4 sectors to unlock and by the time I was nearing the end of the 2nd one I was more or less done with the gameplay. You break into the base, you sneak around and you get out. Rinse, repeat.Still a pretty good game though, at least until you get tired of it.

content:
Posted: January 8
												recomended . At first I tried playing none stealthy which was a total fail. If you go the rambo way through the main door kicking everyone the hell out it's almost impossible. The key is reading all the dossiers and entering and hacking the bases and prototypes the way the dossier recommend, that's the way the game should be played. Read everything !!! and fetch all the intel you can, that's the key. I really don t play stealthy games a lot but I liked this one, haven't finished everything but every mission is refreshing and well presented, maybe one flaw is that it has zero replayability because the maps are fixed none procedual. Neat game recommended .EDIT: Finally I finished it, I was not wrong before, it's a really good game. At the end it gets more combat action especially in the final mission. So maybe you can play stealth three or two scenarios but then avoiding combat is really difficult and has to be well planned. It's not stealthy in the way of Invisible inc, is something else is trying not to bring to much units over you, if two or three catch you it's ok you can deal with them, (when you get stronger and update perks and skills you can deal with much more enemies), but if all the enemies that are in the base are at your tails you are done. IMO is a tactical game more than a RPG as other comments suggested , it's the tactis of dealing with the right amount of enemies and taking the best route to the objective and inflicting damage to the enemy where most it hurts. That's how I can summarize it

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1
												As of writing this review I have just finished the final mission, credits rolling etc.In a nutshell, if you have the patience and skill for micro-managing 4 individual characters with a variety of skill-sets in real-time, I think you will enjoy this game. Obvious comparison being the Syndicate series, which this is supposed to be the spirtual successor. Story (4/10) It is a little flat in terms of presenting its story, which amounts to major developments when you move from one district to the next with a little audio snippet from your Handler, but other than that you get most of your story from blocks of text relating to the mission objectives, or the assorted terminals scattered across each district. It does round up nicely, if somewhat very abruptly with a nice piece of music playing which adds some nice atmosphere. Gameplay (8/10) While not completely flawless, and somewhat slow (as if viewing a video at 3/4 speed, though this might have something to do with my PC) it is a very well put together game. I only had a couple of moments where it glitched out, mostly where 2 of my Agents would either stand still regardless of input, or get stuck in the world geometry, and I mean only 2, during my last 2 hours or so of gameplay, though some mechanics did require some key spamming to get the desired effect sometimes throughout my playtime. Gameplay can be somewhat repetitive, as for each district you generally have the same set of objectives to complete in order to continue your long standing goal, but the thing that offsets this is that because of the mechanics and set-up for said objectives, it feels different each time. A good example is the Bank. Each district has a large branch of the Cities major corporate bank, which you can go and smash open for a lump sum of cash, and increase the amount of money you get over time from the hacked ATM's which scatter the City. While the same objective exists in each block of the city, they each have different defenses and physical layout, prompting you to approach each objective in a different way.The shootouts your agents get into can often feel frantic and overwhelming at times, and more so as the game progresses and you meet more impressive enemies. Careful positioning and use of your Agents abilities will see you survive these encounters, or alternatively, just run away, as the Enemies do seem to suffer from short-term memory loss now and again.That said, with regards to the Stealth aspect, its is very hit and miss. While the enemies you encounter tend to follow the Sight/Sound rules much like Splinter Cell for example, if you do wind up in a colossal shoot-out for which you are not prepared, breaking line of sight and moving a good 50 metres away from the hot-spot seems to cause the AI to think "No problem anymore, back to patrol." which does seem odd, considering that there is now a massive whole in that gate which I blew open with a grenade not 5 seconds ago.All in all, while Stealth is certainly viable with assorted EMP gear/Sound Suppression/Cloaking equipment and silencers for your weapons, take the advice of Gabriel Angelos, "Walk softly, and carry a big gun.", because if your luck is anything like mine, you may need it. Your Agents With regards to the 4 Agents under your control, you have your Soldier, Support, Hacker and Infiltrator. Each has their own skill set up, with both passive and active ablities relating to the role they are designed to fill.  The Soldier is the man with all the guns and explosives with a side of technical gadgetry, allowing him to rewire certain bits of hardware such as doors and power generators. The Support helps keep people alive with med-kits (although these can be equipped by anyone, the support gets the most use from them) and increased passive healing for themselves and the team.  The Hacker gets you into fun and exciting places by opening doors, disabling surveillance cameras and hacking into ATM's to help with cash-flow, as well as the various enemies you encounter, by "hi-jacking" them. The Infiltrator can get into interesting places via vents and ziplines without any aid, can use a sniper rifle to decent effect, and pifler anything shiny thats not nailed down when sent into a building.Each agent can be equipped in various ways with the variety of gear, weaponry and augmentations that you will pick up over the course of the game, new items of which will require researching before you can mass produce them for your Agents, because while you can equip your shiny new weapon or augment immidiately onto an Agent, should they be killed in combat, you will permanently lose it. So I thorougly recommend researching anything new that you may want sooner rather than later. Graphics (7/10) While certainly nothing to get excited about, the visuals of the game to make for an impressive display, even with the almost over-powering presence of neon lighting all over the place, but this can be addressed simply by turning off the bloom. Sound/Music (10/10) The sounds and music of the game are a joy to listen too. Gun fire and explosions feel just right, with a satisfying weight to them. The music is very atmospheric for the most part, each of the 4 districts having its own ambient track, both when wandering the streets and getting into trouble. Overall, I would recommend this game, though I would advise to buying it on sale along with the soundtrack.

content:
Posted: September 9, 2015
												When it comes to dark future scenarios few capture my imagination more than roaming through glittering cities full of neon skyscrapers and augmenting my fleshy bits with chromed up hardware all the while fighting the large corporations that pretty much run the world. Cyberpunk stories have been around for decades and there’s a reason that they’re still popular today. They’re mostly modern retellings of David and Goliath, the “little guy” versus the “untouchable juggernaut”. And Satellite Reign certainly holds true to these tropes in an action RPG that’s a very viable alternative to Shadowrun Returns and its expansion games.http://cliqist.com/2015/09/09/taking-big-boys-satellite-reign/

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 30, 2015
												I really like this game.  It's graphically gorgeous, the tone is savvy, the missions make you think, firefights make you break a sweat every time.Then there's a few hickups, or heart attacks, depending on the player.First issue I had was the lack of tactical pause in the game.  I can buy into the 'this is a RTS, no pause and giving orders' but I've played a number of games that featured that construction (Pillars of Eternity, Starcraft, Age of Empires 2, a few others).  They have this bullet-time thing to replace it, but it costs energy and it covers the screen in this effect that makes me dizzy. If you're not going to impliment tactical pausing, then there should be number 2.Auto-Attack.  I don't know how many times I lost my... we'll call them minions, because they were detected and rather than go hot, they just sucked up the damage.  It gets worse when you have three squads (one of your minions can 'hijack' NPC's and make them allies) and I'm making a firefight while one of my minions sneaks into the fortress and does her mission.  Well... in the course of that time, Squad 1 kills its target and goes to cover, squad 2 goes to cover, I select another target and another, I'm flipping between three squads trying to keep them alive.  It's not fun, it's stressful.  If that's your thing, all power to you.Another issue is that the game still feels like a beta (probably because it just left it).  I haven't seen an issue with graphics (through there is this haze that makes me want to clean my monitor sometimes) and I've only had two instances in 10 hours where my minions got stuck; but pathfinding is sketchy, the auto-attack is missing, places where your minions should take cover aren't available to be used as cover, the sniper (while powerful) is missing a stealth kill function (they have a one-shot kill system if you've not been detected, but your sniper takes about 2 seconds to fire which is 2 seconds your character will be seen and shot at, if it takes that long to make a kill like that, make the time frame longer and with the sniper's range, or half the range, not point blank).Combat feels like a punishment than a method.  Unless you're a excellent micromanager who can manage up to eight characters at the same time.  The auto-attack would make it feel more viable, instead I usually reload or retreat when combat hits because (at the start) your characters are underpowered compared to the opposition which forces you into the stealth system (fortunately, the devs implemented a mission system to relieve the strain after a little work).On the up side:  The Devs are very active and the community isn't toxic.  I've posted a few times and the community was quick on the uptake.  The Devs are explaining their thought process and are open to suggestion,  and I'm hoping that my issues are resolved in the next patch (I mean, if you add auto-attack, this game would rock and roll with a bass drop).Hopefully this game is like a wine that get's better with age (and I'm excited for them to open a workshop/mod system because this game would rock more when the modding community get's its hands on it).  It has so much potential and (for the most part) it's living to that potential.  But it needs a few layers of polish still.  If you decide to purchase this game, you'll get a strtegy game that forces you to plan your movement and the decision to attack is a heavy pro/con system, but you'll get some of the lack-features that really can be irksome (check in a few weeks and hopefully all those issues will be patched!)

content:
Posted: September 13, 2015
												Outstanding, if occasionally uneven game.  The good:  cyberpunk stealth and occasional direct action.  More importantly, it is just plain fun.  I cannot remember the last time I got up in the morning and went "Oh, I want to try...".  The game is deeper than it appears with multiple paths to most solutions.   The bad:  The missions and loot appear to be entirely randomly driven.  This is not a show stopper, but I will say that through some poor luck, I had several missions all ending at the same heavily fortified location.  The answer...go somewhere else in the city for a while.   Don't get stuck thinking you need to clear a district to leave a district.  The other major negative is that your operatives have just enough AI to be stupid in a firefight and will not retreat or move when instructed in some cases.All in all, this is a great game and only getting better.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2015
												I've been gaming for 25 years, loved the original Syndicate/Wars, backed this via Kickstarter and was suprised at the level of quality from the game based on the funds raised.Unfortunately at release the pathfinding was broken.  I gave it 3 months (which you've pretty much had to to with all PC games from the beginning of time) and its now improved.  But still kind of broken. I won't go into the great moments and missions I had in the syndicate games, but the greatest thing about those games (which has yet to be replicated) was sending all 4 agents off to do different strategic tasks, like assassinate, blow up bank, stand ground with persuaded citizens and mow down enemies, infiltrate base steal hover car and fly to a point where all agents meet from all corners of the map to extract.Although it might be a performance issue:i7 Processor6GB DDR3 Ramx2 HD5870 ATI Video cards64 Bit Vista OSBut until they get it working you'll never get those moments in this game because pathfinding doesn't work.  I'm gonna shelve it for now, and see if 5 lives patch it some more.  It's a step in the right direction as I didn't expect to see a game like this ever again.  If it is a performance issue then maybe I need to hack into the national grid with an upgraded machine and make the winter nights even darker by the amount of power needed to run the game.

												I'm seasoned enough in this industry to have bought and played Syndicate Wars when it original came out.  This is probably the best revival of a series I have experienced. content:
Posted: December 28, 2016
												Top notch game. I was a big fan of Syndicate and Syndicate Wars. This game was fantastically new and familiar. I would recommend, but my feedback for the developers in the sequel would be please try to make it a little less linear in terms of development. The way to play is supposed to be non-linear, and this works. However, all you really do is steal blueprints for the next dev, and when you have them all the game is over. I would like to have things still to do once I have upgraded all my units. Also, in the original syndicate there were a lot of different types of missions, like assassinations and so on. These are minimal here, really the whole deal is about getting hold of blueprints. I liked the assassinations and persuading scientists missions from the original games. I also liked getting an income from owning regions, which isn't really present in Satellite Reign. So, I would DEFINATELY recommend this beautifully, playable and addictive game for anyone who played Syndicate or anyone who missed out, but I would like a few more options in future releases.
