content:
Posted: July 8, 2016
												I WANT to like this game.  I really really do.  I grew up playing Syndicate and this could have been a good sequel to it.  Everything about this game is really well done.  Hats off to the developers for attention to detail.So why am I not recommending this game?  It's too darn hard.  I've tried and tried and tried to play it and my party gets wiped on almost every mission.  I've scoured the web to improve but there's not a whole lot out there.  It's not fun when you die constantly.  I don't enjoy that.  Maybe it's just me and I suck.  If so, so be it.I would really like to see a selectable difficulty level on the game.  Easy mode, Normal Mode, Ultra-Hard Mode, etc...  Spawning is an issue in my book.  Whenever you get detected, the waves of enemies keeps spawning and spawning and spawning getting progressively harder with each wave.  Once you're discovered you're pretty much screwed if you think you can stand and fight.  You HAVE to run and hope to find a spot to evade detection which seems very hard to do.  Even if you're hiding, they always seem to magically detect you eventually.  Very frustrating.If you like really hard games and you enjoy the challenge, you'll probably like it.  If you're like me and want to "casually" play and actually have fun, then then I wouldn't recommend it.  And for the record, I completed XCOM and XCOM2.  Those were quite challenging but still loads of fun.

content:
Posted: August 30, 2015
												I was thrilled to see this game come out of early access. I heavily considered backing it during its Kickstarter campaign due to my love of cyberpunk, but had already contributed money to other projects. The game does a some things right, particularly with its setting, but fails in so many other areas that I cannot recommend it.I've only played the game for 3 hours and felt like I was fighting the controls the entire time. - Often I'd place a sniper in a high position only to watch her refuse to take a shot at anyone below once the combat start. Occassionally she would run down an elevator to join the other combatants, getting gunned down the entire way. There's no way she didn't have line of sight to at least one of the army of enemies below her.- Any time I tried a stealth kill with a silenced weapon, the character would run up to arms length with the target, who would trun around at the approach and initiate a gun fight. Outside of the tutorial these stealth kills never once worked. - Characters I'd moved around for a wide flank would end up getting flanked themselves by one of the enemies that seem to come from every single direction. Not so much a problem in itself, but while I was focusing on my other two operatives, the two moving around to flank would completely ignore anyone shooting them in the face from 5 ft away unless expressly told to return fire. There is no toggle I know of for characters to automatically return.- Weapons must be manually drawn, meaning I needed to pull out the weapons for each of my characters if they got into a fire fight. Clicking on enemy would not automatically instruct the characters to pull out their weapons, which made absolutely zero sense.I could go on, but these represent that major annoyances encountered in just the first few hours. The above, however, does not include the bugs.- I crashed to desktop every single time I tried to exit to main menu or load within the game.- Cars in the game could be seen doing sharp donuts in the middle of a high security facility. Cars also seem to pass right until my operatives, who launch over them and back onto the ground as if nothing happened.- Enemies spawned from alarms return to their doors and run in place agains the door, sometimes stacking up to 3-5 enemies stacked on eachother fruitlessly running into metal for no reason.Satellite Reign is severely flawed both mechanically and operationally and still feels like an early access/unfinished product. The game desperately needs a pause feature, more information on chances to hit and the benefits of cover, stealth kills that actually work, info on character line of sight, and so much more. This is a tactical game that removes your ability to operate tactically and as such needs a lot of work.

content:
Posted: September 5, 2015
												This is a good base for a better game to be built off of.The world is big, but has nothing really holding it together. You just run from compound to compound doing missions which... have little to no story to them.The story is almost nonexistant if you don't bother reading all the extra materials.The complete lack of variaty in weapons, augmentations, and gear can be terrible frustrating.Enemies are gigantic bullet sponges, more often than not your guys will never hit when shooting at them, unless you tell them to more often than not they won't even fire back to save themselves.Unless you don't want them to, in which case they will.This game needs a smaller venue with more focus on missions, rather than an open world.A smaller more narrative focus will benifit it greatly because without that... well, I couldn't tell you why I did anything in this game beyond the need for better gear.It needs more weapons, more augmentations, more gear. And it would be even better if researching the various things unlocked more hidden items.The ability to pause would be a godsend.The ability to easily differentiate between friends, foes, and civilians would be nice. More often than not they all blend together except on extreme zoom, or for the occassions where you're facing the heaviest opposition.Personally I enjoyed the style of gameplay, but this game itself was boring and frustrating.I see lots of potential for a sequel if they fix the problems.But after the ending do I recommend this game? Ugh, that ending made it a no.No, I forced myself through in the hopes that something of value was going to happen and what do I get? Out of nowhere (spoiler censored) nonsense and a really... really bad pun.If you want this, wait for a sale. Or some serious tweaking.

content:
Posted: September 5, 2015
												A wonderful game for when you want to bang your head against the wall untill the blood flows, this game drove me potty until I finally realised what was wrong and unistalled it. This thing is a sod to play, thanks to the checkpoint save system and the totally random natures of the stealth encounters. you can get ten minutes into a perfect stealth intrusion and then get it blown by one error, which invariably results in a firefight. At that point you either quit and start from scratch, wasting ten more minutes getting back to the same point, or you fight it out, at which point you might have well just started shooting the second you started the mission and saved yourself some time. I wasted an entire saturday trying this and just got fed up with it. Uninstalled. Wish I hadn't brought it.-----------Slightly changing my opinion on sunday. Re-installed and gave it another shot. Still s**t. the camera angle being fixed is dumb, makes everything harder and wholever chose that on the Dev team needs to get slapped. the checkpoint save system still makes everything artifically harder. It needs way more worldbuilding. some very dodgy gliches, like watching an infiltrator with a SNIPER RIFLE running right up behind a guard and sniping him. from five feet away. Apparently, stealth kills have to be done from close range. Nice to know, you should have made that clear. Why doesn't he change to the pistol? since killing guards is core gameplay, why didn't this bug get fixed? So many stupid little things, that just show how limited the develpoment of this game really was. gliches and bugs. gameplay errors. this game is a damning inditment of modern game development, ambious but deeply flawed and far short of its potential. It can be fun when you win, and i have been playing it for two days now. But this game is seriously unwhelming and frustrating.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2015
												This game is half done gameplay. The only good things relatively well done are the stealth, the graphics and the animations of the whole town, and the writing is ok but nothing great, and that's it.The combats means controlling real time 4 characters with zero pauses and they have ZERO AI!!! Any RTS do much better since 20+ years, lol. There's covering, movements, weapons switching and targeting, if a character get shoot he doesn't fire back nor even go in cover, the controls are still rather bad, and there's a lot of abuse of enemies spawning. That's ridiculous.The economy is also ridiculous with a system where you just wait time to get more money. For sure some missions allow get more money but that free money mechanism break all and pinpoint the inability to build a true gameplay.Other than that everything else is at level of a casual game, hacking is a simple click and a short cooldown, rob a bank is a simple click, and so on.

number of helpful: 5 of 14 people (36%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 12
												As much as I wanted to like this game, the economy just completely killed the game for me. In order to keep you agents with decent equipment you need to research them, which costs a ton of cash, and most of the cash you get in game is through a passive ATM hack. The problem is that even when you're actively pursuing objectives you never have enough money to research the required equipment. Since the enemies scale with your team's level, I felt outmatched by the enemies before I completed the first area. You have the ability to buy new equipment, but most of it costs 10k-20k and I was getting at most $3 a minute.The game pauses after any length of inactivity, so there's really no way for you catch up with the curve.I enjoyed the strategy, but the lack of funds to keep my team going, and what appeared to be RNG equipment drops, just killed my enjoyment of the game.

content:
Posted: July 22, 2016
												This game is mediocre at best. If you are desperate to revisit your gilded memories of Syndicate Wars on DOS, this might be your fix. All others should exercise caution. I'll put this in simple STEAM review pro/con parlance:PROs:+ Depth: Quasi-customizable character models with numerous options for tweaking your squad of agents. Includes various weapon types, mods, and augmentations that cater to multiple play styles.+ Art: Well done cyberpunk art direction. The game world is accented with plenty of neon to break up the urban dystopia.CONs:-Annoying, unskippable tutorial that seems intent on shoving blinking boxes in your face.-Clunky, unsatisfying combat. Picture a smooth, flowing river. Now picture a dude trying to take a♥♥♥♥♥♥after sex. It's the latter one.-Lame auto-scaling enemies ensure you are almost always out-gunned if you want to "go loud". -Tedious, grindy missions.Short story long? I kept asking myself "Why aren't I playing something like XCOM?"

number of helpful: 2 of 8 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17
												TLDR: if you want the Syndicate experience go to GOG and get Syndicate, gg&wp. If you want to try Sattelite Reign which is not and no where near Syndicate, well, enjoy. If you are a fan of Syndicate like myself and want to buy this game because of that reason, I suggest don't, not even on a sale because it'll probably leave you sorely disappointed.The way missions work, the way augments, ammo, utilities and weapons gathered are completely different. For example in Syndicate people you killed dropped weapons which you could pick up, there would be missions to get scientists and tech for research. There were missions for money and to recruit agents. There are missions here as well but all the missions are on the same map, there's no base, there's no globe (yet loading screens...). This big map with smaller districts have all your missions in it and your agents never leave that field, there is no base hence pretty much no management aspect. You siphon money from ATMs and that's it. Recruiting scientists? Nope. There's this "bribe" mechanic basically you go around "scanning" random NPCs or mission NPCs and bribe them for various reasons. Recruitment works in a similar way, you scan a dude, hijack him and "send him back" as clone material (you may go "the what material?") well it turns out you use people as meat to recreate your dudes but then the meat people you hijack and send back... oh my f**king god... are listed as they are and can be used as they are. So you clone your guys' minds to new bodies or some sh*t I don't know. Anyway the screen where you set your active agents is designed in a way to make you want to break your keyboard. You want to click on a new guy to see his stats? Sorry, no can do, you recruited that git you're stuck with him forever. I guess they all start the same? Nobody knows, it's a mystery, forget about it! There are 4 slots in your group: soldier, support, hacker, infiltrator and you set a guy's job hence abilities as they level up by clicking on the slot then clicking on a guy but it gets so messy, good god a pot head must have designed that thing, or maybe someone on bath salts.Weapons work in a weird way too. You invest a crap load of money to research a better(!) gun then end up emptying clip after clip on a lowly guard but then can 1-shot assasinate someone with a lower tier pistol. Just like in real life? Sure, why not? Oh and one sucky thing is you can knick any cars, no driving in this one.Graphicswise it's not amazing, music, voice-over work, sound effects are generic and poorly done. AI & pathing can be quite funny, you shoot a guard down for example, his buddies show up, you run around a corner and hide and a short while later they say that the suspects have gone and then you can come out of hiding and say hello, they won't know it's you or you have to tag a building for a mission (basically most if not all your missions involve going to the designated building, entering it then exiting it and you're done) it's surrounded by guards, you double click, your guy runs in, by the time cameras or guards notice him he's out and running back (LuL), or a guard of one faction can waltz in to the base of a different faction and since all guards can pass through gates it starts a small faction war for no reason (sometimes messing up your progress). Similarly messed up paths of civilians sometimes crossing into a restricted area can cause all hell to break loose too.With the amount of bugs even though not that much but can find you at the worst possible time you might think: "hey, that's what quicksaving is for". Nope, sorry champ, there is no quick saving. Autosaves are frequent and you can manually save but the game won't put you where you saved, instead you spawn at the last beacon you visited (because immersion). Long story short, you can't try anything for science, this game hates science it seems. No shenanigans allowed.

content:
Posted: July 16, 2016
												Not worth buying!Overall i realy want to like this game. but NO! Too much failed gameplay elements for a good game! It makes fun for around 5 hours till than the game is ruined.It seams to be some kind of tactical somehow, be sneaking-in steal information and go on, but there to much unbalance to make this game fun. Like the XCOM series its leveling up, do missions and upgrade your units - that makes real fun and is the best part of the game till the point where no more upgrades make sense und you do the same as at the beginning only against a overcrowed bunch of overupgraded soldiers. You have better weapons but its against higher hitpoints, there is no balancing for this. The NPC only are upgrade according your gear and your fight exactly the same again only with higher hitpoints. the missions are quiet always to same, that would not realy be a problem because some possibilies to make diffrent chooses (like use a vent for stealth instead of shooting) but its always to same. go to the at hardes secured area, always after lotting be invaded by alot of high soldiers and mostly your death, beside the fact you absolute stealthed in, there are always alarm... realy senselessThe open world is realy great, very cool ambient. To bad it's mostly ruined the gameplay that the low soldiers running around try to kill you without any reason, only kill at sighn. they die you have to wait that the timer go down and than next way to to mission or more shooting. if not soldiers try to attack you some of the security cameras always reports. put you guns out and you have alert, let it in you have alert to... run and maybe already run into soldiers. alert = fight...The missions are sometimes realy funny, pribe a person to get information, use a person to get key information for easier entrance. but after all its only running around, click on them and mostly they are useless. you do it anyway by the mostly obvious easiest entrance and you have mostly more success than as the mission logs described. some of the mission absolut makes no sense. if you got in there you got bad loot for a high death rate. the loot is quietly always to same, blueprints and a mission description. use it to get better weapons are arms and after all the enemys get stronger and you have absolute no progress for looting it. very sad.

												Have to run it at 960x600 at otherwise lowest graphics settings to get anything approaching decent FPS.Criticism 1 here: Even as is i see many effects on that do not need to be on, weather effects, shader effects, etc. If there were more options the game could be tuned to run fine on higher resolutions.Criticism 2: Sadly, at that resolution the UI is completely unusable, since the fonts are tiny and blurred into smudgy messes, and you're expected to make use of buttons that are mere pixels across.If they fixed either of those, it be good to play, but as it is, if you have a weak-ish machine, i cannot recommend this game.

number of helpful: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2016
												Satellite Reign is an engaging and stylish homage to the classics. It includes all the improvements you'd expect from the last 20 years of game design theory: A high-contrast neon cityscape to play through; your operatives  have classes rather than being interchangeable; the game is set in a single sprawling, explorable location and, of course, it has multiplayer.  Satellite Reign feels like the game Syndicate would have been if it were conceived with the advantages of 2010s design theory and hardware. Highly recommended to fans of the genrel, or anybody who likes cyberpunk ambience and realtime squad-based action.

content:
Posted: March 3
												It's just not good.It's a real time tactics game in which the tactics are "shoot the guys."  You don't get to make a lot of interesting decisions, and the stealth is kind of laughable.  I wish this game were good, because it looks great and it has a great premise, and I credit the developers for delivering what they promised. But it just isn't engaging, interesting, or satisfying to play.It's lacking in tactical depth, and tries to make up for that lack of complexity with the cloning system that lets you grab random passersby and turn them into agents.  Yeah, just what I wanted, to run around looking at the stats of random civilians to determine who has a +1 I can use.How about you add some interesting dimensions to the tactical play instead?

number of helpful: 4 of 18 people (22%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												DO NOT BUY THIS GAME!The game has one of the most amazing concepts ever. Literally ever. I want a game like this SO BAD.This game, however, is a steaming pile of garbage. The controls simply DO NOT WORK. There is a system of having your weapon drawn or holstered. Holtered means you can walk around undetected, and that works fine. Drawn weapon draws attention, but you can fire at people. This...doesn't work. I have all my agents with weapons drawn, I click to attack something, and they all just run from cover like excited puppies that need hugs. They charge up and proceed to get shot in the face OVER AND OVER. Finally, after a few full blown shotgun blasts to the face, they start to fire back...from...out in the open.The tutorial will teach you that you can hide REALLY close to a guard and not be noticed. I had one on the other side of a chest-high wall I was crouched behind not notice me SEVERAL times. Once you get out of the tutorial though, oh HELL NO! I get spotted from across the map while in cover in a few moments flat.This game had all of the potential in the world, but instead took a dump and asks you to eat it.0/10, do not play, do not buy, do not look at. Don't even contemplate. I wish like crazy I could remove this pile of garbage from my library, but Humble Bundle means no refund.♥♥♥♥ this game.

number of helpful: 7 of 27 people (26%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
												This review has a lot of my opinions in it, and doesn't necessarily reflect my objective review of the game as a whole. In addition, I only made it through the tutorial before making my mind up about it. So, to digress: I'm a HUGE fan of the cyberpunk genre, and when I heard of this game's release I pretty much exploded. It was exactly what I was looking for in a game: huge, open-world environment, player-character customization, and of course the cyberpunk aesthetic. Add that the game is on sale currently and I bought it almost immediately. I was extremely excited, sat down, lights turned down, and launched the game.It was extremely boring.It was the letdown of the century: the gameplay was tedious, the environment had no life, it just lacked any sort of fun. Believe me, I tried to look past this for the sake of the fact I was playing a cyberpunk game but the novelty soon wore off. For me, it just wasn't what I was looking for. If you're a detail-oriented, micromanaging player who doesn't mind a bit of monotony here and there, then Satellite Reign might be just up your alley. But if not, and you feel monotonous gameplay might get on your nerves, give this one a pass.

content:
Posted: August 28, 2015
												This is a review that I will constantly update as I play more and get more feels for the game. But since everyone downvotes it because they don't agree with me I might as well write this: WORST GAEM EVURZ LOL DYE NUBS because the voting system on steam is more ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t than this game.The game suffers from several flaws that I feel could make the game a lot better:1. The enemies have two sets of flashlights, White and Yellow. When Yellow they are looking for you, but haven't found you yet, and White, everything that isn't yellow, all from not knowing about you to outright attacking you (This can be annoying as you never know if they're running towards you to kill you, or running past you.2. You can target enemies that your agent cannot attack properly, making them shoot at an impenetrable wall all for nothing. Another thing that is a real bother about your agents and shooting is how, while there is a way to make them move and attack as they meet targets, there are no ways of making them stay in cover, and shoot at any target, you have to micromanage it so incredibly deep.3. A lot of the game is based on you having to micromanage everything, from setting up every agent, choosing their targets, using their abilities, and ressurecting fallen agents, all while under fire from multiple locations, having enemies come from all directions and leaving you to either stay where you are (Which mostly ends up killing you) or running up against the enemy in a hail of bullets to get a better position. Neither is very fun to choose.4. When in a gun fight you want to get into cover as fast as possible, so if you happen to get your agents not standing in cover, you'll want to mark them all and click on the closest cover, right? well this game punishes you for it because actually clicking for them to get in cover or just standing next to cover is pixel-close, easily making your agents just wander around in a damn ugly dance.5. Movement is very forced, your agents don't change direction or turn corners with anything but ugly drunken stagger, whenever they reach a corner they stop for a split second before shambling into the new direction.5.1 The movement get's extra terrible when trying to Stealth Kill enemy guards, due to if the guards turn a corner your agent will first run to the place they were when you clicked them (Even if it's out of the way), then they will take the same drunken stagger around the same corner the guard did, and then they go after the guard! (And hope that it didn't turn any more corners as it'll make even more drunken staggering on your side!)The game is very unforgiving, there are security cameras everywhere, guards randomly patrolling, something simple like hacking an ATM machine can become a fight where the game throws everything and the kitchen sink at you, and the ATM hacks are giving such small rewards you begin questioning the games intent. You always wish you have 4 hackers and 4 assassins just so you can kill everything without being heard and hack everything because your hacker needs to be in so many places at once.So far I can say that if you want a casual game, Don't get it.If you like RPGs where you have soooo much options (you're able to Force some actions, like hacking, to happen, but without the right skills your agents can die to RNG and alert nearby enemies to his location). But you also need to think extremely Strategical as you are constantly surrounded by enemies and have to think fast, even if you've planned greatly. You also need to micromanage the game on an insanely deep level that I've explained earlier in the review.HOWEVER, the game feels incredibly great when you have managed to get past a certain objective which has given you problems for a while.BUT, the game seems to punish both Guns Blazing and Stealth styles as stealth is very easy to screw up and requires a lot of work, most of the time by one or two agents leaving the other two to just stand and hope not to get outflanked while you're busy. Likewise the Guns Blazing option gives you a better feeling for loosing, since you're going in blazing! It's to be expected if you screw up, but it's still easy to be outflanked, outnumbered, not having the opportunity to shoot down alarming guards, and you're having to out-micromanage a computer. ♥♥♥♥ that!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 24, 2016
												Commandos + Syndicate Wars = Satellite ReignIts punishing, doesn't hold your hand or spoonfeed you. It can be frustrating and occasionally annoying. However, I love it. Very open ended. A great sandbox to exercise your creativity. Excellent for those who love strong, emergent gameplay.You basically control 4 agents - Infiltrator, Soldier, Hacker and Support - in a surprisingly large sandbox of a city. It's not a GTA like open world, but feels lived in and atmospheric. You break into secure facilities and steal stuff. Method of approach is up to you. Plays a lot like Eidos's Commandos franchise, where you sneak around enemy bases.The Agent's skills, the equipment and augmentations make all kinds of playstyles viable and fun. Hijack enemies and create a slave army, sneak in with suppressed weapons or blow up the main gate with Miniguns and grenades - its a very flexible game. NOTE: AI quirks and inconsistencies can make the experience frustrating, especially for new players. It gets a lot better after the 8 hour mark. Play this if you have a lot of time at hand and like long game sesions.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2015
												If you liked the original Syndicate, you will like Satellite Reign. This game brings back a lot of memories.  SR is open world with some nice UI overhauls and other added game play features, but plays very much like the original.   Augment your agents, go in sneaky or guns blazing.  Think of it as what the new Syndicate should have been.  A few minor bugs, but nothing game breaking.  One was really funny as my plasma beam got stuck on with infinite ammo so it just mowed down everything as I walked through the base.   It will take a beefy computer to run it on ultra.  With 780ti and 4470K and 16 Gb ram at 1920x1200 res everything was on max and it was averaging 56fps with drops into the mid 40's, but still very playable.  16-20 hour play through if you complete all tasks.   Very much recommended.

												Basically my fetishBe a cyber terrorist in a cyberpunk world. Spend 30 minutes just harassing local law enforcement and murdering them. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 11, 2015
												Satellite Reign was kickstarted on the idea that it's a modern Syndicate Wars. On that basis it actually... isn't that great. The quintessential experience of having four hulking trenchcoated replicants shooting through crowds and buildings with miniguns isn't there, or if it is, it's near or at the end of the game. Satellite Reign is actually its own beast, and the squad of cyborgs you command is actually a lot more like four individual "hero" units from RTS games. There's a distinct advantage to stealth, so the hacker and assassin did (for me) get more use than the other two (heavy weapons and "support"). I don't think this is really an oversight, they just did stealth right, and wanted to avoid making the heavy weapons guy a man-tank at the beginning of the game.It's got bugs and problems. Everything does. The ending is dumb, but not unreasonable. I don't feel like any of the problems are serious enough to warrant inclusion in this review.SR was made by a team the size of early Introversion Software, and for a first effort, it's fantastic. I played the Shadowrun Turn-Based game, but I feel like this game is a lot closer to the RPG, and I actually kind of wish someone would re-create the Second Edition cover with Satellite Reign units. I liked this game a lot, but I think that $30 is kind of pricey for an isometric shooter. Buy it when it's $25 or less. I suspect it'll be $20 come Steam Winter Sale, and for $20 you should BUY IT for sure.

content:
Posted: October 25, 2015
A spiritual successor to syndicate that improves on the original.Mechanistically, this is a birds-eye real time simulation of a small team of agents in a cyberpunk setting. The inspiration from bullfrog's syndicate is obvious, yet this game manages the impressive feat of improving on that original.I absolutely love that you can approach your objective in a number of different ways... Yes, you can tool up and go in guns a-blazing, but you can also sneak in one or two agents to try and complete the mission without raising any alarms... or mind-control the right guard, or bribe a disgruntled ex-employee, send your soldier to cause a distraction on the opposite side of the compound, and so on.bugs/issuesI have had a few issues with escorted characters sometimes getting stuck when going through vents. (as of 2015.10.25, may have been patched since).

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 30, 2015
												I'm struggling to stop playing this game. I remember spending many an afternoon after school playing its spritual predecessor Syndicate, and then many years wishing someone would make a more modern version. This is everything I hoped for and more. The genre is a little hard to pin down - perhaps a mix of Deus Ex, X-Com (but realtime) and something like Commandos - but that doesn't really do it justice. It's a large open-world, with many different possible paths - pure stealth, stealth killing/assassination or plain frontal-assault. Combat isn't usually plan A, but it makes a very fun plan B if your carefully laid plan goes to pot. It's had me on the edge of my seat during missions so many times and I'm probably only two-thirds of the way through. I suspect when I finish it I'll have another go and make some different choices too.

content:
Posted: September 25, 2015
												There's an obvious question to ask about Satellite Reign:I loved Syndicate - will I like Satellite Reign?The simple answer is yes, from the very moment you get to the main menu, the style and feeling of Syndicate suffuses this game, even down to the fact that the UI sounds brought back warm fuzzy feelings to me.It's not just an updated reskin of Syndicate though - fundamentals are there, but Satellite Reign feels a little more sophisticated and mature, as you would hope after over a decade in which for the has become more sophisticated and refined as a whole.But this leads me to a second, prehaps less obvious question:I loved Commandos - will I like Satellite Reign?The simple answer is again yes. In case you're not aware, Commandos[en.wikipedia.org] was a stealth heavy game where you had a group of soliders each with a unique set of skills. You'd need to use these skills in coordination to complete the missions, and the same is very much true of Satellite Reign.Fortunately for me, I loved both of the above games and therefore I can't get enough of Satellite Reign :)

content:
Posted: October 25, 2015
A spiritual successor to syndicate that improves on the original.Mechanistically, this is a birds-eye real time simulation of a small team of agents in a cyberpunk setting. The inspiration from bullfrog's syndicate is obvious, yet this game manages the impressive feat of improving on that original.I absolutely love that you can approach your objective in a number of different ways... Yes, you can tool up and go in guns a-blazing, but you can also sneak in one or two agents to try and complete the mission without raising any alarms... or mind-control the right guard, or bribe a disgruntled ex-employee, send your soldier to cause a distraction on the opposite side of the compound, and so on.bugs/issuesI have had a few issues with escorted characters sometimes getting stuck when going through vents. (as of 2015.10.25, may have been patched since).

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 3, 2015
												Pros-Enjoyable game.  The game allows you to tackle objectives the way you want.  You can smash your way in or sneak.  I play a combination of the two.   Map design is good that it makes choices on making those objectives enjoyable.  The Art and music are fitting the game.  Nothing seems out of place.  Controls work well.  Leveling and character outfitting is well done and makes sense.Cons-The game play has some quirks.  Path finding issues, small problem but noticeable if not careful.  The factions act as enemies and allies at the same time.  If you hijack a person of another faction and bring them in to another factions base they will attack them, but if you alerted a faction and run into another faction will attack you as if they were on the same side. Also rare but noticeable is when your character gets stuck on terrain. Conclusion- Buy this game.  The issues with the game are not major and will probably get fixed with a patch.  Fun experience for me so far.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 4, 2016
												This game was clearly made by a bunch of passionate people who played the old syndicate and loved it. I haven't played syndicate for many long years, but I couldn't help remembering it while going through this one. The old one was repetitive as hell, and this one did improve somewhat on the recipe by adding some layer of story on top of each mission, but it's still more or less of the same gameplay mechanics throughout, peppered with upgrades and various powerups to spice it up.For those who did not play the old Syndicate, this is a real time and squad based action game, where you control 4 agents in a futuristic cyberpunk city, reminescent of the movie "Blade runner" where it's always night time and raining. Each agent has core skills common to every agent, and a few special skills specific to their profile (soldier / hacker / support / infiltrator). You tackle various missions spread all over a big map starting low in equipment and firepower and slowly building it up.I liked the art, the environment and the music very much, and although the AI was dumb it did not stop me from liking the game. I felt like I was playing the old game again, but having grown older I viewed this game with my 2016 eyes and experience and I think that this game is a worthy successor.[edit after some checks] actually some of the devs worked on the old syndicate so that explains why the game feels so true to its ancestor.

												are you a Commandos fan?well buy this game! cause its your futuristic cyberpunk Commandos-like game.are you a XCOM fan?well buy this game too, cause its your real-time strategy XCOM!now lets rant about the awesomeness of this title:AGENTS: Satellite reign is a real time tactical squad strategy game, god that was mouthful...anyway you control four agents each with certain set of skills (Class Based as mentioned in its description) so you have a soldier as your frontliner and damage soaker/dealer, you have a support/medic that can heal and operate as a team leader and buff your other agents, a hacker that can hack atms and security doors/cameras and also HIJACK people how awesome is that!, and of course lastly my favorate class the assassin that can snipe people from a far or slice them up and close in stealth, your agents level up and you spend their points the way you want your agents to perform you can also customize your agents with augmentations from techs you steal and research, buy awesome laser and plasma prototype weapons and also a variety of gears each with a certain purpose to it.MAP: now lets talk about the map, the game has a HUGE map different districts to get access to and a lot of corporations that you need to infiltrate and encounter in order to progress and aquire techs, you can travel through the map by walking and that take time cause its really huge, or you can respawn your agents using becons scattered around in every district.Objectives: the game offers a variety of objectives and different WELL THOUGHT AND IMPLEMENTED ways to achive those objectives, through bribes, recruiting informants, hijacking indeviduals and sometimes getting your hands dirty and bloody to get informations.Satellite reign is a 10/10 game for me, the game offers everything a tactical squad game player can hope for, the only downside for me is there is no voiceover for the characters and since I am a creature driver by sounds I find that side lacking, everything else is perfect.thanks for reading

content:
Posted: July 12, 2015
												My previous review was positive.Having played the game past the tutorial, I'd say think twice before buying this. It's finicky, repetitive (even very early on) and you'll be repeating missions until everything lines up correctly (i.e. by chance) There's very few ways to do missions and the loading times are very long. So enjoy that. The controls are also poor, as is pathfinding. My agents have been stuck inside buildings and walls several times which leads to reloading again. And don't forget - you can't save inside a mission, so you're right back at the start. How ♥♥♥♥ing wonderful is that? I bet you want to punch the idiot developer that made that decision right? I sure do.♥♥♥♥♥ on the corpse of the old syndicate, but slightly less so that the other remakes.It's also very buggy. Agents get stuck inside buildings, disobey your orders and if left alone, will just comply with arrest orders (even if you've told them to run away beforehand, you'll have to do so again). This in a game without pausing and being able to give orders.So yeah, do you want to deal with all that ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t?

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												Satellite Reign is a real-time, class-based strategy game. You control a team of four agents, each with distinct and unique abilities, collectively battling for control of a fully simulated, living cyberpunk city.The game world is designed to facilitate emergent gameplay, giving you the tools and freedom to play how you want to play, so you can create strategies and scenarios that not even we had anticipated!Customise your team with the strength to destroy your enemies head-on, or hack into their facilities to manipulate their infrastructure without them ever knowing you were even there.Will you take down your enemies with brute-force? Covert espionage and infiltration? Or will you use propaganda to influence the citizens of the city and overthrow the controlling powers?

												Co-Op evaluation, Stable for the most part. There were many benifits to playing Co-op. I controlled the soldier and infiltrator while my buddy used the Hacker and Support. After 1/2 way through the game when it before more combat viable i took over the Support and we really laid waste to everything. Also the hacker gets to take over other units so he needs more focus to manage his squade while i still had mine. Stability, For the most part the game was very stable and there was not much lag at all. He mentioned a little bit of clunkyness but this was felt by me also. a few times the game would not register the attack of one unit. There was a bug where i had an extra soldier and infiltrater spawn. I had to exit the game and enter single player to zone into another area because the checkpoint door did not transition us due to the game thinking there was 2 people not present for the transition. The extra members also had no gear and we had to force kill them then reload single player to get rid of them. Not many issues other than that, mildly annoying.Finished, (no spoilers) We finished the game in about 26 hours. 6 of the hours were afk time while we saved up money before the big fight. We both enjoyed the game and highely recomend this game to anyone who enjoys the coop experience. 9/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 28, 2016
												8.5/10If you need a crew of terminators to unambiguously murder it's way into destroying a rival corporation on a blade runner-esque backdrop, this is your game. It's a blast. I think I got this on sale for 15 bucks and it was worth every penny, if not more. I have some thoughts on the ending and the future of this game at the end of this review.Graphics: Gorgeeous, gritty cyber-punk, it's always night time and it's almost always raining. I wished for more camera control. The Unity engine it was built on did an impressive job.Gameplay: This is a real-time strategy squad control game. If you're familiar with Syndicate and Syndicate Wars, then you know these games can be frustrating. Controlling 4 agents in a fast-paced gunfight is not easy. You won't regret taking the Team Stims skill early on. This allows you to slow down time so you can make good tactical decisions when♥♥♥♥♥♥hits the fan. Speaking of which, the game is very "sandbox", -you can take a stealthy approach or go in guns-a-blazin', and there's no penalty for mindlessly slaughtering every thing in your path, including innocent civilians. Make no mistake, this game does not punish you (unlike Deus Ex) for killing innocents. So go ahead and enjoy some collateral damage. I felt free to take on any mission I wanted at any time, in any order. I could start a gun fight anywhere for no reason at all, rob a bank, or do missions to collect blueprints, prototypes and research upgrades for my agents.Sound: I have nothing to say here, except it's good.Music: The music in this game is awesome. The 'battle song' never got old, kicking into a solid beat when bullets start flying.Story: The 'back story' if you can call it that, comes through when you hack data terminals. It's easy to miss, but you get copies of emails that you can read. Through these various emails, a rather intricate plot starts to unravel between the 3 rival corporations (The Eternals, UzyKorp, and Dracogenics). I feel like the devs, who built this game un roughly half a million USD (an impressive feat TBH), had to cut a plot-driven ending and gave us something else entirely. I liked it, but it might not impress everyone. tldr; If you like cyberpunk, GTA-style freedom, Syndicate, Syndicate Wars, buy this game. Personal note for 5 Lives Studios: I LOVE this game. But I also see soooo much potential here for more. The story revealed through hacked emails didn't translate in the gameplay and I'm wondering if there's opportunity here for a sequel. There' a ton of mod potential here too, and I missed that. Custom cities, models, missions, weapons and augs would add a lot of replay value. I would totally throw down for another kickstarter.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 15, 2016
												This is an incredible game that the author never bothered to write a manual for, and left out too much in the tutorial.  You must read the manual guide first.I played the original Syndicate all the way through around the time it came out.  This is a worthy and much improved successor.  It adds a lot of elements that the original game didn't have, and has much better gameplay and a lot more depth.  Also, the fan provided steam controller profile works well, this is a good game for a steam controller.The combat feels great, and so does the preparation and stealth.  It isn't too easy like the original Syndicate.  In the original, you could just stand there with miniguns and kill all comers without much thought or difficulty if you did a little bit of prepositioning.  This one requires a little more thought and tactical awareness, and makes stealth effective, while still leaving Rambo style invasions viable.  It reminds me of Deus Ex, in that there are many ways to do the same objective, which I love.The load time when you first start the game is really slow, but don't let it put you off.  The way the game is designed you shouldn't need to load the game unless you just started it up, even if you die, so it isn't really a problem during play sessions.  The game will not punish you significantly for dying as long as you do not use prototypes in combat.  The cloning decay mechanic on death is quite gradual, and does not go below 0.  The tutorial left me thinking that I had to load or I would be kneecapped - but that is totally unecessary.READ THE GUIDE WITH THE FANMADE MANUAL FIRST!Read the guide that is a fanmade manual for the game before you start.  The tutorial misses important gameplay elements and is a bit buggy, sometimes repeating parts when you load unnecessarily.  Retreating to the beacons lowers your alert level more quickly, and the game needs to tell the user this, but does not.  It's really important.10/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 19, 2016
												Didn't know what to expect when I got this game, but was totally smitten by its premise. Set in a dystopian future where the city is run by greedy, unscrupulous, amoral megacorporations. You emerge as a rival corporation set to bringing down the big bad megecorp that has the monopoly on Immortality.You start off small and you need to build up your resources by infiltrating and stealing from other rival corporations. Weapons, Cybernetic implants, Money, Gear are all up for grabs as you build up to prepare for the final showdown. It is an open-world environment where you extend your will through your four agents. Each are a different class with their own special functions to help you go about waging corporate espionage. Most jobs have more than a few ways of going about, from guns blazing thru the front door to softly softly approach via zipline. You can customise the weapons, gear and implants to further whichever playstyle mix you choose. I say mix because you're going to need to be able to switch between going Loud and Quiet when things don't go your way.It takes a bit of getting used to for figuring our stealth and combat. There aren't any visual representation for line of sight so you'll have to be patient to get the feel for what the enemies can see and which cover will hide you from them. Otherwise knowing directional cover, using flanks, silent takedowns, agent abilities are keys to waging effective corporate warfare.Game is not without its imperfections however. AI can sometimes do stupid things at times. An Infiltrator with silenced sniper rifles screwing with patrols till they are all picked off without sounding alarm for backup is an example of the limitations of the AI. Your agents and enemies sometimes get stuck in the environment on rare occasions, forcing a suicide for affected agent. When alerted, enemies seem to develope eyes on the back of their heads to catch your agents going the other way while ignoring the big obvious distraction you've set up.But overall this game should keep you entertained for at least 40 hours depending on pace. But if you want a teamplay element added to the mix or you find it too hard to manage 4 agents all at once in realtime, there is a co op feature where you can have up to 3 other friends control an agent each, tho i find it easier just playing with one other player and just controlling 2 agents.

												I purchased expecting a mostly modern take on the old Syndicate game. I was not disappointed. Great graphics and depth to the upgrading of your agents. Plot line is pretty basic. Gameplay is a bit overwhelming at first but the complication is very rewarding later when you find that you need to try different strategy. Easily one of the more entertaining games in my library.This game does require a fair amount of thinking how to approach a scenario. And, to up the risk/reward, there is no pause, so your strategy has to be workable in realtime AND account for changes. The guards might look like they're walking a static route but they can and do change the route randomly! It makes for a much different type of strategy game than you might be used to from turn based games. You should really have at least a plan B for when it all goes wrong. If you don't, you're going to get crushed.8.5/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 17, 2016
												NOTE: THIS GAME IS GREATLY CPU INTENSIVE, MAKE SURE YOU HAVE A BEEFY CPU!The review: After finally getting a cpu that can play this smoothly, this is a great game that was made by the developers of the original syndicate series, including syndicate and syndicate: wars. Do not let the syndicate from 2012 give you a tainted view on what was once a top notch game series, as these devs had nothing to do with it. Satellite reign is the spiritual successor to syndicate and syndicate wars, bringing new features and combining it with the old. If you have played the older syndicates then you most likely know what youre getting into, however if you havent then keep reading. you play the role of a CEO opperating a hostile takeover of this city after corperate corruption has overdone politics, you remotely control an elite team of 4 cloned operatives to do your bidding, research new tech and expand your secret corperate empire by taking control of the assets of your enemies. using your modified clones you will kill, steal, wreak havoc and coherse your way through an insanely detailed open world from a birds eye point of view. the controls are rather simple and the AI could have been improved a bit more but overall this game does the classics more justice than the shooter reboot in 2012. i do recommend getting it if youre a fan of the classic syndicate or if youre looking for a uniqe strategy/tactical experience.

												Good as crap. That's really good where I come from. I think the linear quest style and free-roam blend really well here. I like the extreme damage mode, it makes combat more realistic and decisive, requiring a more calculated approach. The concept of increasing characters base stats through genetic cloning of random people that you have scanned is very refreshing. SR hits a lot of the right notes but there is a blandness to it all that I can't quite put my finger on. I think it stems from the lack of variety in the environment and atmosphere, such as sounds and interactions between NPC's. The city is populated with moving bodies that do little else. That is forgivable however seeing as how they really serve no purpose besides upping your crews stats with their DNA. The save system is frustrating...

Get it.

content:
Posted: May 9, 2016
												It is very clear that this game was set out from the start to be the successor in spirit if not in name to Syndicate, and although it could have been a lot more if it'd done just a little better during the kickstarter, it's still succeeded at being a worthy successor in many regards. Differentiating the roles of your four core team members helps a lot to diversify the experience, and lets you try your hand at a lot of different playstyles instead of having one cookie-cutter build you apply to all cyborgs. Gameplay can get a bit repetative at times, but the levels are well designed and the difficulty ramps up well, and there's usually many different approaches to get to where you need to go, and the many side quests that give you some small bonusses and your opposition some small penalties are nice as well.

Posted: April 16, 2016
												are you a Commandos fan?well buy this game! cause its your futuristic cyberpunk Commandos-like game.are you a XCOM fan?well buy this game too, cause its your real-time strategy XCOM!now lets rant about the awesomeness of this title:AGENTS: Satellite reign is a real time tactical squad strategy game, god that was mouthful...anyway you control four agents each with certain set of skills (Class Based as mentioned in its description) so you have a soldier as your frontliner and damage soaker/dealer, you have a support/medic that can heal and operate as a team leader and buff your other agents, a hacker that can hack atms and security doors/cameras and also HIJACK people how awesome is that!, and of course lastly my favorate class the assassin that can snipe people from a far or slice them up and close in stealth, your agents level up and you spend their points the way you want your agents to perform you can also customize your agents with augmentations from techs you steal and research, buy awesome laser and plasma prototype weapons and also a variety of gears each with a certain purpose to it.MAP: now lets talk about the map, the game has a HUGE map different districts to get access to and a lot of corporations that you need to infiltrate and encounter in order to progress and aquire techs, you can travel through the map by walking and that take time cause its really huge, or you can respawn your agents using becons scattered around in every district.Objectives: the game offers a variety of objectives and different WELL THOUGHT AND IMPLEMENTED ways to achive those objectives, through bribes, recruiting informants, hijacking indeviduals and sometimes getting your hands dirty and bloody to get informations.Satellite reign is a 10/10 game for me, the game offers everything a tactical squad game player can hope for, the only downside for me is there is no voiceover for the characters and since I am a creature driver by sounds I find that side lacking, everything else is perfect.thanks for reading

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 20, 2016
												I've been a massive fan of Syndicate and Syndicate Wars since their releases. They've consistently been some of my favorite games and I've always remembered them very fondly. Here's what's different this time:Corporations are monolithic institutions with control over every facet of the world. The police are omnipresent, but if you get caught by them, they're just as likely to beat you and rob you as they are to arrest you. Everything you see is connected to a network which can be exploited to breach all sorts of security. Civilians are everywhere, but they don't really do anything other than walk around aimlessly and have no real purpose.Oh...oh THE GAME! The game, right. Satellite Reign is awesome and it's an excellent Syndicate game. If you liked Syndicate you should check it out. If you loved the Syndicate games, you need to buy this one.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 24, 2016
												Commandos + Syndicate Wars = Satellite ReignIts punishing, doesn't hold your hand or spoonfeed you. It can be frustrating and occasionally annoying. However, I love it. Very open ended. A great sandbox to exercise your creativity. Excellent for those who love strong, emergent gameplay.You basically control 4 agents - Infiltrator, Soldier, Hacker and Support - in a surprisingly large sandbox of a city. It's not a GTA like open world, but feels lived in and atmospheric. You break into secure facilities and steal stuff. Method of approach is up to you. Plays a lot like Eidos's Commandos franchise, where you sneak around enemy bases.The Agent's skills, the equipment and augmentations make all kinds of playstyles viable and fun. Hijack enemies and create a slave army, sneak in with suppressed weapons or blow up the main gate with Miniguns and grenades - its a very flexible game. NOTE: AI quirks and inconsistencies can make the experience frustrating, especially for new players. It gets a lot better after the 8 hour mark. Play this if you have a lot of time at hand and like long game sesions.

content:
Posted: June 20, 2016
												If you enjoy cyberpunk you'll enjoy this game.I picked it up a while ago, only have maybe 30 minutes  and I sucked at the game (I still do now to some extent) but after feeling really in the mood for a cyberpunk game I decided to play it again. Got through the first mission, did a couple of bits and bobs in the world and oh my god I can't believe I skipped on it before.The strategy is fun, the story is interesting and the whole city design itself captures the cyberpunk feel perfectly.Every time I enter a restricted area and a tense skulking about followed by a firefight (avoidable if your good unlike me) keeps me engaged. However I recommend playing in bursts as it can seem monotonous in the way you move around the city.The different classes, (Soldier, Support, Hacker and Infiltrator) are a nice balance between Uniqueness and Similarity. To put it simply a Soldier  could  hack a terminal but a Hacker does it better. A Hacker  could  fight off the local Security forces but a Soldier does it better. The beauty of this is, is that it means you're never limited in options which is crucial when things come down to the wire.Overall the game is fun if you're craving something cyberpunk in a pinch but can also become kinda boring when played in large intervals. So I shall give it a 7/10.

content:
Posted: April 21, 2016
												Satellite Reign is a very good proof of concept that truly captures the mood and feel of the classic Syndicate games. What isn't asked though, is if that is a very good idea. I remember the Syndicate games feeling old only a few years after their release. The combat controls just weren't precise enough and the environments and missions felt samey.Reign's story, limited though it is, makes more sense than Syndicates, one long night of bringing down a corporation. It too suffers from average controls, lacking in finese to get your agents to do what you want. In stealth and hacking, the game succeeds. That is why I recommend this game. It's satisfying and very well made, but the game they were emulating perhaps wasn't the best idea. It is very good that a carbon copy was not made.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 26, 2015
												I'm giving this a positive rating because it's quite enjoyable, but I want new buyers to be aware of something.I found this game really fiddly to play, in the way that a game from the 90s would be fiddly to us now. Some of the UI/UX concessions we are used to are not here. The biggest issue is that there is no AI on your squad members, so they don't indulge in sanities like returning fire when being fired upon. The game doesn't even notify you when your people are getting shot, it just happens silently. It would have been preferable to have a simple rule: When your weapons are drawn, get to the nearest cover and return fire.I'm also sort of clumsy and prone to mis-clicking and sending my people around to the wrong side of cover. Games like this usually have tactical pause, and normally I just pause and reissue the command. But Satellite Reign doesn't have a pause mode, it only has a 'Team Stim' skill that slows time for about 5 seconds and then takes a few seconds to recharge. It's not bad, it's just different, but 'different' can be hard to get used to.

												If you liked the original Syndicate, you will like Satellite Reign. This game brings back a lot of memories.  SR is open world with some nice UI overhauls and other added game play features, but plays very much like the original.   Augment your agents, go in sneaky or guns blazing. content:
Posted: June 3, 2016
												I love this game.  I played Syndicate (1993) to death, and this is the best successor that I have yet seen.I guess it took some time after the kickstarter to get some of the bugs ironed out and the performance dialed in -- but I missed out on that.  By the time I started playing, it ran smooth and I didn't encounter any problems in my first 40 hour playthrough (maybe some of that was idling time).I found it to be smooth and polished.  I enjoyed the cyber-noire story and it was worth finding all the terminals to make sure that all of the narative was revealed (I did use some maps I found online for this, as well as the Steam achievemnents list so that I would know when I found all the terminals in a given zone).There are lots of valid aproaches to playing.  You can go loud and shoot everything up, or use brain-jacked agents to open all the doors as you speed-run through, or take your time and stealth everything.  You can even stealth the final boss fight if you have the patience for it.Now that the coop beta is out, I expect to give this a lot of replay.  I have a few friends in different time zones that I think will play, and each group can keep its own persistant multiplayer save.I usually review games with a list of caviats and qualifications, but in this case I have none. I have no detractors to caution you about, and endorse this wholeheartedly.Do check through the forums though, as it seems some folks have some complaints.

content:

												Co-Op evaluation, Stable for the most part. There were many benifits to playing Co-op. I controlled the soldier and infiltrator while my buddy used the Hacker and Support. After 1/2 way through the game when it before more combat viable i took over the Support and we really laid waste to everything. Also the hacker gets to take over other units so he needs more focus to manage his squade while i still had mine. Stability, For the most part the game was very stable and there was not much lag at all. He mentioned a little bit of clunkyness but this was felt by me also. a few times the game would not register the attack of one unit. There was a bug where i had an extra soldier and infiltrater spawn. I had to exit the game and enter single player to zone into another area because the checkpoint door did not transition us due to the game thinking there was 2 people not present for the transition. The extra members also had no gear and we had to force kill them then reload single player to get rid of them. Not many issues other than that, mildly annoying.Finished, (no spoilers) We finished the game in about 26 hours. 6 of the hours were afk time while we saved up money before the big fight. We both enjoyed the game and highely recomend this game to anyone who enjoys the coop experience. 9/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 4, 2016
												This game was clearly made by a bunch of passionate people who played the old syndicate and loved it. I haven't played syndicate for many long years, but I couldn't help remembering it while going through this one. The old one was repetitive as hell, and this one did improve somewhat on the recipe by adding some layer of story on top of each mission, but it's still more or less of the same gameplay mechanics throughout, peppered with upgrades and various powerups to spice it up.For those who did not play the old Syndicate, this is a real time and squad based action game, where you control 4 agents in a futuristic cyberpunk city, reminescent of the movie "Blade runner" where it's always night time and raining. Each agent has core skills common to every agent, and a few special skills specific to their profile (soldier / hacker / support / infiltrator). You tackle various missions spread all over a big map starting low in equipment and firepower and slowly building it up.I liked the art, the environment and the music very much, and although the AI was dumb it did not stop me from liking the game. I felt like I was playing the old game again, but having grown older I viewed this game with my 2016 eyes and experience and I think that this game is a worthy successor.[edit after some checks] actually some of the devs worked on the old syndicate so that explains why the game feels so true to its ancestor.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 26, 2016
												I haven't played Syndicate so my review is only going to be based on what a player new to the franchise perceived. Love the idea, some great visual tricks and an excellent soundtrack. It's unlike anything I've ever played but the best analogy would be an xcom in real time.And now for the bad: everything else. The micromanagement is endless and can get very frustrating because your agents will not do ANYTHING by themselves, including returning fire. You even have to select a new target every time you kill one, which also interupts any channeling skills you might be using on the respective agent immediately placing it on cooldown. I can't count the amount of times my agents run out of cover for no apparent reason during the round-robin click-fest of combat and or the amount of times they attempted to shoot through unbreakable walls/barriers instead of moving to a better firing position.The levelling system seems completely useless. Everytime you level up or get a new piece of kit, all enemies magically get some kind of equivelant. Just got your first shield? Congratulations! Now every man and his ♥♥♥♥ing Patrol Dog too! Armour? We got that when you first hit level 5! Lasers weapons?! You must be new here...They should have just removed the levelling/equipment aspect and just given you everything from the start because there is absolutely no reward for smashing your face into a wall long enough to level up enough or finding those prototypes deep in enemy territory. Atleast that way you're on the same level instead of playing catch up the whole way through.The stealth system is the only option. However when you inevitably fail because of some random patrol or camera you're most likely going to die if you can't run away and hide from the endless amount of obscene enemy forces that spawn. So do what I did and destroy cameras (even though it will alert/ spawn guards) and shut down generators, and stealth kill as many patrols as you can so atleast your deaths aren't meaningless right? Wrong. Cameras respawn, generators turn back on, and patrols respawn incredibly quickly. I once hit the pause button to invest in a new skill only to find when I returned a patrol had respawned from thin air right in front of my face.There's challenging and then there's padding combined with punishing you for overcoming that challenge. If you enjoy the latter, then get this game, but I can not recommend a game that I will probably never finish. For all those hours I only reached what I think is about halfway.

												This is a kickstarted game based on bullfrog's Syndicate genre. You play cybernetic agents in a cyberpunk world. Your job is to infilitrate corporations by killing troops, by passing cameras and turning off turrets and gates. You can play stealthily or guns blazing. You can upgrade your agents with augments that giver better stats, weapons or possess higher quality clones. You use these clones so you can respawn if one of your agents goes down and dies. Technically you can just respawn and rush the enemy compound but respawning early costs money and it is not that easy to obtain it. Interesting that one of the biggest backers from Kickstarter is the main villain Stephen Dengler. You get to fight him in the end :). Word of warning, it starts slow but it gets better and better towards the end. 7/10.

												Note that this is only after playing 5 hours. This is a game that I will play still, but there is a bit left to be desired from it. It is a decent remake of a game I loved from the past called "Syndicate" by Bullfrog studios from the early '90s. Strangely enough, while both games are playable and indeed enjoyable, they both lack a certain refinement that I am struggling to articulate. It's almost as if there's too much information, while at the same time not enough logic to it. Ultimately I end up confused as to what's important in the game, what I'm really trying to accomplish, and how certain upgrades benefit the mission. Robbed a bank, spent the funds on a prototype to research and promptly found the prototype for free after a simple mission, but hamstringed myself unnecessarily for hours in the first area. It's as if they used the same blueprint for the "Syndicate" without improving any of the confusing camera angles and warning systems or immsersion with the actors. 5/10 will still play it though at least for a once through. Grab it if you can on sale.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 11, 2015
												Satellite Reign was kickstarted on the idea that it's a modern Syndicate Wars. On that basis it actually... isn't that great. The quintessential experience of having four hulking trenchcoated replicants shooting through crowds and buildings with miniguns isn't there, or if it is, it's near or at the end of the game. Satellite Reign is actually its own beast, and the squad of cyborgs you command is actually a lot more like four individual "hero" units from RTS games. There's a distinct advantage to stealth, so the hacker and assassin did (for me) get more use than the other two (heavy weapons and "support"). I don't think this is really an oversight, they just did stealth right, and wanted to avoid making the heavy weapons guy a man-tank at the beginning of the game.It's got bugs and problems. Everything does. The ending is dumb, but not unreasonable. I don't feel like any of the problems are serious enough to warrant inclusion in this review.SR was made by a team the size of early Introversion Software, and for a first effort, it's fantastic. I played the Shadowrun Turn-Based game, but I feel like this game is a lot closer to the RPG, and I actually kind of wish someone would re-create the Second Edition cover with Satellite Reign units. I liked this game a lot, but I think that $30 is kind of pricey for an isometric shooter. Buy it when it's $25 or less. I suspect it'll be $20 come Steam Winter Sale, and for $20 you should BUY IT for sure.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 28, 2016
												8.5/10If you need a crew of terminators to unambiguously murder it's way into destroying a rival corporation on a blade runner-esque backdrop, this is your game. It's a blast. I think I got this on sale for 15 bucks and it was worth every penny, if not more. I have some thoughts on the ending and the future of this game at the end of this review.Graphics: Gorgeeous, gritty cyber-punk, it's always night time and it's almost always raining. I wished for more camera control. The Unity engine it was built on did an impressive job.Gameplay: This is a real-time strategy squad control game. If you're familiar with Syndicate and Syndicate Wars, then you know these games can be frustrating. Controlling 4 agents in a fast-paced gunfight is not easy. You won't regret taking the Team Stims skill early on. This allows you to slow down time so you can make good tactical decisions when♥♥♥♥♥♥hits the fan. Speaking of which, the game is very "sandbox", -you can take a stealthy approach or go in guns-a-blazin', and there's no penalty for mindlessly slaughtering every thing in your path, including innocent civilians. Make no mistake, this game does not punish you (unlike Deus Ex) for killing innocents. So go ahead and enjoy some collateral damage. I felt free to take on any mission I wanted at any time, in any order. I could start a gun fight anywhere for no reason at all, rob a bank, or do missions to collect blueprints, prototypes and research upgrades for my agents.Sound: I have nothing to say here, except it's good.Music: The music in this game is awesome. The 'battle song' never got old, kicking into a solid beat when bullets start flying.Story: The 'back story' if you can call it that, comes through when you hack data terminals. It's easy to miss, but you get copies of emails that you can read. Through these various emails, a rather intricate plot starts to unravel between the 3 rival corporations (The Eternals, UzyKorp, and Dracogenics). I feel like the devs, who built this game un roughly half a million USD (an impressive feat TBH), had to cut a plot-driven ending and gave us something else entirely. I liked it, but it might not impress everyone. tldr; If you like cyberpunk, GTA-style freedom, Syndicate, Syndicate Wars, buy this game. Personal note for 5 Lives Studios: I LOVE this game. But I also see soooo much potential here for more. The story revealed through hacked emails didn't translate in the gameplay and I'm wondering if there's opportunity here for a sequel. There' a ton of mod potential here too, and I missed that. Custom cities, models, missions, weapons and augs would add a lot of replay value. I would totally throw down for another kickstarter.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2015
												I'm giving this a positive rating because it's quite enjoyable, but I want new buyers to be aware of something.I found this game really fiddly to play, in the way that a game from the 90s would be fiddly to us now. Some of the UI/UX concessions we are used to are not here. The biggest issue is that there is no AI on your squad members, so they don't indulge in sanities like returning fire when being fired upon. The game doesn't even notify you when your people are getting shot, it just happens silently. It would have been preferable to have a simple rule: When your weapons are drawn, get to the nearest cover and return fire.I'm also sort of clumsy and prone to mis-clicking and sending my people around to the wrong side of cover. Games like this usually have tactical pause, and normally I just pause and reissue the command. But Satellite Reign doesn't have a pause mode, it only has a 'Team Stim' skill that slows time for about 5 seconds and then takes a few seconds to recharge. It's not bad, it's just different, but 'different' can be hard to get used to.

Posted: June 20, 2016
												If you enjoy cyberpunk you'll enjoy this game.I picked it up a while ago, only have maybe 30 minutes  and I sucked at the game (I still do now to some extent) but after feeling really in the mood for a cyberpunk game I decided to play it again. Got through the first mission, did a couple of bits and bobs in the world and oh my god I can't believe I skipped on it before.The strategy is fun, the story is interesting and the whole city design itself captures the cyberpunk feel perfectly.Every time I enter a restricted area and a tense skulking about followed by a firefight (avoidable if your good unlike me) keeps me engaged. However I recommend playing in bursts as it can seem monotonous in the way you move around the city.The different classes, (Soldier, Support, Hacker and Infiltrator) are a nice balance between Uniqueness and Similarity. To put it simply a Soldier  could  hack a terminal but a Hacker does it better. A Hacker  could  fight off the local Security forces but a Soldier does it better. The beauty of this is, is that it means you're never limited in options which is crucial when things come down to the wire.Overall the game is fun if you're craving something cyberpunk in a pinch but can also become kinda boring when played in large intervals. So I shall give it a 7/10.

content:
Posted: June 3, 2016
												I love this game.  I played Syndicate (1993) to death, and this is the best successor that I have yet seen.I guess it took some time after the kickstarter to get some of the bugs ironed out and the performance dialed in -- but I missed out on that.  By the time I started playing, it ran smooth and I didn't encounter any problems in my first 40 hour playthrough (maybe some of that was idling time).I found it to be smooth and polished.  I enjoyed the cyber-noire story and it was worth finding all the terminals to make sure that all of the narative was revealed (I did use some maps I found online for this, as well as the Steam achievemnents list so that I would know when I found all the terminals in a given zone).There are lots of valid aproaches to playing.  You can go loud and shoot everything up, or use brain-jacked agents to open all the doors as you speed-run through, or take your time and stealth everything.  You can even stealth the final boss fight if you have the patience for it.Now that the coop beta is out, I expect to give this a lot of replay.  I have a few friends in different time zones that I think will play, and each group can keep its own persistant multiplayer save.I usually review games with a list of caviats and qualifications, but in this case I have none. I have no detractors to caution you about, and endorse this wholeheartedly.Do check through the forums though, as it seems some folks have some complaints.

Posted: May 9, 2016
												It is very clear that this game was set out from the start to be the successor in spirit if not in name to Syndicate, and although it could have been a lot more if it'd done just a little better during the kickstarter, it's still succeeded at being a worthy successor in many regards. Differentiating the roles of your four core team members helps a lot to diversify the experience, and lets you try your hand at a lot of different playstyles instead of having one cookie-cutter build you apply to all cyborgs. Gameplay can get a bit repetative at times, but the levels are well designed and the difficulty ramps up well, and there's usually many different approaches to get to where you need to go, and the many side quests that give you some small bonusses and your opposition some small penalties are nice as well.
